Mon, Nov 15, 2021, 21:41:59 - pietervdvn: Hi all!

I've made a MapComplete theme that is built to help importing buildings based on the GRB. It isn't finished at all, but I already want to share it with you because:

- it is already useful
- I want to poke up the discussion about the import process.

You can find it at https://mapcomplete.osm.be/grb?language=en&welcome-control-toggle=true#welcome

The very long term goal of this project is to make it easier to import, less error prone and to even automate parts where no human oversight is needed (e.g. in unmapped areas or places where GRB got updated).


If you have any remarks, ideas, feedback, ... please do post it in the according github issue here: https://github.com/pietervdvn/MapComplete/issues/564

However, right now, I don't have a lot of time, so I'm not gonna improve the theme for at least the following weeks .

At last, right now you still need a plugin to make this theme work to bypass some security. Unless @gplv2:matrix.org is so kind to allow "mapcomplete.osm.be" and "pietervdvn.github.io" in the CORS-header. So: Glen, would you be so kind to open this up please? ü•∫

Mon, Nov 15, 2021, 21:49:21 - joost_schouppe: I gave it a shot before. Not production ready at that time, but looked quite promising. Especially the conflation logic could be a real timesaver.
Mon, Nov 15, 2021, 21:55:35 - pietervdvn: Yeah, the conflation logic is the main reason I did build it. The very long term goal is to zoom to an area, MapComplete does all the stuff it is 100% it can be safely _imported_ and uploads it and asks some confirmation for some weird stuff. ANd if that is tested, we could even let it run loose on Flanders... But that is still a long way of

Tue, Nov 16, 2021, 09:43:19 - s8evq: Not sure if I'm doing it wrong though 
Tue, Nov 16, 2021, 09:43:20 - joost_schouppe: oh
Tue, Nov 16, 2021, 09:44:58 - joost_schouppe: that's weird
Tue, Nov 16, 2021, 09:45:47 - s8evq: It's a cool thing with a lot of potential. But indeed, work in progress. For example, I updated the GRB tags on a building, without actually also updating the geometry of the corresponding nodes. That could mess things up.
Tue, Nov 16, 2021, 09:45:56 - s8evq: I'll make a githun issue for that missing address
Tue, Nov 16, 2021, 09:49:48 - joost_schouppe: oh, the tool is stripping away the address on upload!
Tue, Nov 16, 2021, 09:52:58 - joost_schouppe: pretty nifty that it can merge nodes of adjacent buildings
Tue, Nov 16, 2021, 09:58:13 - joost_schouppe: this is the address logic I'd propose:
Tue, Nov 16, 2021, 09:58:14 - joost_schouppe: Addresses logic
- never upload addr:flats by default
- do not show ALL crab addresses by default
- if a building has a single address, upload address-on-building to OSM by default
    - edge case: building has address from two different streets, but somehow GRB didn't realize > if a CRAB address is on top of a GRB building that does NOT include that address, do show that CRAB address
- if a building has more than one address:
    - and all the CRAB address nodes are on the same XY, DO upload address to OSM by default
    - and there are CRAB address nodes on more than one
- if a building has NO address, always show CRAB addresses if they are on top
- if a CRAB address exists, and there is no building nearby that contains that same address, DO show the address
Tue, Nov 16, 2021, 10:17:24 - joost_schouppe: if you look at an area that has already been mapped, the tool is already quite intelligent!

Sat, Nov 20, 2021, 21:55:47 - stijn_claes: Message deleted
Sat, Nov 20, 2021, 22:14:07 - stijn_claes: <@joost_schouppe:matrix.org "staat dat al ergens beschreven o..."> Ik doe dit meestal als volgt. Bijvoorbeeld voor deze situatie: https://goo.gl/maps/EuScm4Ko524MVKHV7. Is dit correct?
- Copy both the GRB building (gbg) as the GRB building annex (gba) of type 'Verdieping' to the OSM edit layer
- Select both objects and use the shrink wrap tool to create a new objects combining both objects into 1 big object
- Change the building tag of both original objects into building:part=yes
- Add the number of levels to both original objects (tag building:levels)
- Add the number of skipped levels to the building annex object (tag building:min_level) and remove the fixme tag
- Remove the address tags in the original building object and add them to the new combined object. Add a building tag as well.

Wed, Nov 24, 2021, 11:05:35 - LePirlouit: related to fixme building:level and min_level, should I put them together in a multipoligon if there are part of the same building ?
Wed, Nov 24, 2021, 11:08:21 - joost_schouppe: no. Say there are two parts. Then both parts lose the building=* tag and get a building:part=yes tag instead. Then you copy-paste the two parts on top of the originals, merge them and map the one as building=*. The validator will detect the duplicate nodes and can fix them automatically for you
Wed, Nov 24, 2021, 11:08:58 - joost_schouppe: In rare cases, it might make sense to merge more more than two building parts. ANd even rare, sometimes it makes sense to keep the address info on the building parts
Wed, Nov 24, 2021, 11:09:45 - joost_schouppe: When you merge the two building parts (shift+j), you'll get a screen to decide what to do with conflicting tags. For the GRB tags, keep both values with ; separator

Fri, Dec 3, 2021, 13:26:05 - @gplv2:matrix.org: map $http_origin $cors_header {
    default "";
    "~^https?://[^/]\.bitless\.be(:[0-9]+)?$" "$http_origin";
    "~^https?://[^/]*\.byteless\.net(:[0-9]+)?$" "$http_origin";
    "~^https?://grbtiles\.byteless\.net" "$http_origin";
    "~^https?://[^/]*\.bitless\.be(:[0-9]+)?" "$http_origin";
    "~^https?://grbosm\.site" "$http_origin";
    "~^https?://staging\.grbosm\.site" "$http_origin";
    "~^https?://*\.maproulette\.org" "$http_origin";
    "~^https?://maproulette\.org" "$http_origin";
    "~^https?://*\.grbosm\.site" "$http_origin";
    "~^https?://dataviewer\.grbosm\.site" "$http_origin";
    "~^https?://osm\.be" "$http_origin";
    "~^https?://*\.osm\.be" "$http_origin";
    "~^https?://play\.osm\.be" "$http_origin";
    "~^https?://grb\.app" "$http_origin";
    "~^https?://*\.grb\.app" "$http_origin";
    "~^https?://dropchop\.io" "$http_origin";
    "~^https?://localhost(:[0-9]+)?$" "$http_origin";
    "null" "$http_origin";
}

Sun, Dec 5, 2021, 13:03:14 - beardhatcode: Die had ik nog niet ik zal die eens bekijken üôÇ
Sun, Dec 5, 2021, 13:03:32 - joost_schouppe: Belangrijkste punten waar niet iedereen aan denkt:
- gebruik de speciale GRB validator en doe een validatie vooraleer op te laden
- de tool doet al een goede gok van gebouwtypes, maar check die toch nog. Veel tuinhuisjes ed zijn gewoon building=yes; gewone woonhuizen die hun adres zijn verloren zijn vaak ook building=yes
- zwier er de addr:flats gewoon uit, maar je kan die tag wel gebruiken om te checken op appartementen
- check ook goed de adressen. GRB vertaalt die niet altijd proper door vanuit CRAB. Als je het √©cht wil snappen, ga dan naar crab.agiv.be (en maak even een gratis account aan)

Mon, Dec 6, 2021, 12:50:45 - pietervdvn: Hi all,

A [new version of the MapComplete-GRB importer is out](https://pietervdvn.github.io/mc/develop/grb?z=9&lat=51.07419&lon=3.831481&language=nl&layer-type_node=false&layer-OSM-buildings=false&layer-address=false&layer-All OSM objects=false&filter-crab_address=show_matched_addresses.1&layer-gps_track=false). This link will only shows buildings that have to be imported.

It features way better address handling:

- GRB-addresses on a beige plaque and will be imported automatically
- If an not-imported OSM-building overlaps significantly with a GRB-outline, they will be merged
- CRAB-addresses on a fuschia plaque, only shown if not in OSM nor in GRB. The popup features a button to import the address as well, and will snap it to buildings if close enough
- It works 'out of the box' on desktop and mobile (without weird plugins anymore)

This is still very much **in alpha stage**, so this will contain bugs and rough edges! 
- Doublecheck your work in another editor (e.g. click the little pencil in the attribution to open iD) 
- Please, report bugs and ask questions [in this github issue](https://github.com/pietervdvn/MapComplete/issues/564
) so that everything is bundled there

Paging joost_schouppe s8evq @gplv2:matrix.org timcouwelier

Tue, Dec 7, 2021, 18:36:41 - joost_schouppe: Ik denk dat ze echt mensen alles laten nakijken
Tue, Dec 7, 2021, 18:37:49 - joost_schouppe: Bijhouding binnengebieden

Tijdens de bijhouding binnengebieden worden terreingegevens zoals gebouwen, waterlopen en- plassen, spoorbanen en kunstwerken gelegen in het binnengebied bijgewerkt op basis van recente middenschalige luchtbeelden. Deze bijhouding vormt een belangrijke aanvulling op de bestaande terreinupdate van het GRB, waarbij enkel landmeetkundige opmetingen worden uitgevoerd 
Het binnengebied van elke gemeente wordt op de 2 √† 3 jaar bijgewerkt.

Tue, Dec 7, 2021, 19:04:23 - joost_schouppe: hebben we de afgelopen dagen nog heel effe over gehad
Tue, Dec 7, 2021, 19:04:39 - joost_schouppe: ik heb al een veel grotere automated edit op die data gedaan, dus niet echt een issue
Tue, Dec 7, 2021, 19:04:53 - joost_schouppe: Glen had gezegd dat hij er zelf eens naar ging zien
Tue, Dec 7, 2021, 19:21:18 - stijn_claes: <@joost_schouppe:matrix.org "Ben wel benieuwd of ze nog volle..."> Er wordt op verschillende manieren gewerkt:
- Op basis van de middenschalige luchtopnamen die elk voorjaar gemaakt worden, wordt er adhv een algoritme (destijds opgebouwd door AGIV samen met VITO) zogenaamde gebouwmutaties opgespoord. Die mutaties worden dan als anomalie√´n in het proces bijhouding binnengebieden opgenomen.
- Het eigenlijke proces 'bijhouding binnengebieden' wordt aanbesteed en wordt typisch door firma's zoals EUROSENSE, Avineon, Teccon... uitgevoerd. Meestal doen die beroep op goedkopere operatoren in C-EUR, India of China. Ik weet niet juist of het altijd zo is, maar hierbij wordt -dacht ik- niet alleen gevraagd om de bijwerking van de gebouwen te doen (het eigenlijke karteren), maar ook het actief screenen naar wijzigingen.

Ik weet niet hoever men hiermee staat, maar men bekijkt idd ook naar hergebruik van goedgekeurde vergunningen om wijzigingen te signaleren (maar het probleem hierbij is dat men afhangt van verklaring begin en einde werken en daar is de Vlaming niet goed in). Daarnaast is men ook bezig om dit heel proces op een andere manier te benaderen waarbij slechts een 2 of 3-tal firma's zullen instaan voor alle bijhoudingsprocessen van het GRB (met ook snellere bijwerkingscycli, afhankelijk van het type object).

- er een CRAB-address op het huis staat met hetzelfde nummer
- er is slechts √©√©n crabadres met overeenkomstig nummer
- er is een straat in de buurt met een identieke schrijfwijze

Daarnaast gaat die tool ook sowieso niet alles oplossen en is import+TLC voor een lokaal gebiedje ook altijd heel mooi. Sat, Dec 18, 2021, 15:09:01 - @gplv2:matrix.org: <@joost_schouppe:matrix.org "op zich kunnen we denk ik gemakk..."> Dat gaat ja, maar dat betreft wel enkel een export, niet perse een import.  Je kan niet meer exporteren zonder een account aan te maken , maar niets weerhoudt iemand ervan om cryptische username/email te gebruiken die je niet kan linken aan OSM account.  Omdat OSM naar mijn weten nog steeds geen Oauth2 ondersteunt kan ik dit niet linken.  Oauth1 is hier gewoon niet geschikt voor (Laravel framework) en ik ga daar niet mee beginnen.    Ik zou idd datamodel wat kunnen aanpassen dat ik bijhou wie export voor eerste keer doet.   Misschien kan iemand reeds een mail adres voorzien waar ik die notificaties naartoe stuur.  Ik kan ook als ik tijd heb BEBOT eens updaten en mss een apart kanaal maken waar BEBOT notificaties krijgt en dan deze pusht in een kanaal hier.  Zijn maar ideetjes ... denk gerust mee

Dit is trouwens een API call, dus dat kan low level aangesproken worden (oa. door BEBOT als ik het implementeer).   Ik denk dat je op dit moment wel moet aangelogd zijn om die exports te zien. (ben nie meer zeker van buiten)
Sat, Dec 18, 2021, 15:11:39 - joost_schouppe: Indeed, export is nog geen import. Maar als je de inhoud van de export kan zien, dan kan je wel snel checken of het bij een test bleef of niet
Sat, Dec 18, 2021, 15:12:49 - @gplv2:matrix.org: <@Seppe:matrix.org "Status van bebot is me niet hele..."> JSON is de way to go hier hoor.   BEBOT is typescript/javascript, native JSON notatie is gemakkelijkste.  Enige lastige is dat hij even uitligt omdat er wat aanpassingen zijn gebeurd.  BEBOT => HUBOT , de populairste met de beste integraties voor slack/matrix etc.   Is eigenlijk niet zo veel werk, maar moet we wat tijd voor vinden.   Zal volgende week eens kijken, normaal heb ik overdag wel wat tijd om daar in te vliegen.

Het pak het geheel wat visueler aan, legt de lat lager voor aantal mensen, doet prima achtergrondchecks, zit goeie logica in om in goede banen te leiden.  GRB tool is altijd al voor mij een hulpmiddel geweest dat low level / experienced JOSM mappers assisteert in te proberen goeie defaults te zetten, acceptabele tags (building = yes bv), en ook heel belangrijk, een manier om backreferences naar GRB te voorzien .  Ik denk dat die refs nu echt wel hun nut bewezen hebben.   Het is een andere insteek/aanpak met meerwaarde imho

Sat, Dec 18, 2021, 18:32:34 - @gplv2:matrix.org: MapComplete gebruikt (optioneel) de API van GRBTool voor een aantal zaken.   Dus het is niet dat de ene de andere uit bestaan gaat duwen of zo.  GRB tool is modulair gemaakt, de interne API (niet zelfde als data API) en de view zitten volledig volgens MVC principe in elkaar.  Een extra Tab erbij is heel simpel hoor,  view bijmaken, menu bijwerken.   Dus alles daar uitbreiden is geen overdreven moeite.  85% van het werk van de GRBtool zat hem in de javascript, daar zit bulk van werk in .   Maar zoals Joost al zei, het gaat over de wiki wat aanpakken.
Sat, Dec 18, 2021, 18:36:53 - @gplv2:matrix.org: Wat betreft data van de andere communes, ik ken URBIS vrij goed, dat is in essentie niet zodanig overdreven moeilijk , als ik PICC nog kan uitdokteren en het valt te doen , dan steek ik alles in 1 postgis database natuurlijk, dan werkt GRBTool gewoonweg over het ganse land,  ik ga aan de interface kant niets drastisch moeten veranderen zo.  Buiten checks voor references , en paar kleinere zaken.   Het enige dat ik nu zie dat ik ontbreek is 3D Lidar data van PICC.  Ik denk dat ik die van URBIS wel kan vinden, desnoods trek ik het intern er wel uit op het werk.    Maar die 3D data zorgt ervoor dat de tags vrij goed gekozen worden.  Als dat ontbreekt is het wat minder interessant, maar nog steeds de moeite.  Er gaat enkel vrij veel op building=yes komen te staan.

Mon, Dec 20, 2021, 10:35:42 - s8evq: Ik ben hier vandaag weer mee aan de slag gegaan. Uiteindelijk gebruik ik geen SPSS of het typescrit script van pietervdvn , maar gewoon via sed en regex. Ik zoek via overpass naar gebouwen waarbij er in de `source:geometry:date` tag een / bevat in plaats van -. Dat openen in JOSM en vandaar opslaan als .osm
In dat bestand  zoeken en vervangen via sed.
En dan blijkbaar gewoon `action='modify'` toevoegen tussen de way id en timestamp.
Bestandje terug inladen in JOSM en uploaden.

Tue, Dec 21, 2021, 20:45:52 - s8evq: `source=GRB` mag gewoon weg
`source:geometry:date`   blijft behouden, maar met - in plaats van /
`source:geometry:entity`   value van deze key gaat nu naar `source:geometry:ref=`
`source:geometry:oidn`     value van deze key gaat nu naar `source:geometry:ref=`
`source:geometry:uidn`   mag gewoon weg
Tue, Dec 21, 2021, 20:46:37 - s8evq: waarbij er dus een nieuwe key zou komen: `source:geometry:ref=_ENTITY_ / _OIDN_`
Tue, Dec 21, 2021, 20:46:40 - s8evq: zoiets?

Thu, Dec 23, 2021, 00:21:49 - pietervdvn: @gplv2:matrix.org: Your service is down ‚òπÔ∏è
Requesting a BBOX result in an error message: 
```
SELECT DISTINCT ON(geojson) pp.osm_id, round((ST_Area(pp.way))::numeric,2) AS size_grb_building, pp."addr:housename", pp."addr:housenumber", pp."addr:interpolation", pp."addr:street", pp."addr:flats", pp.man_made, pp.building, pp.highway , pp.tags -> 'building:levels' AS "building:levels" , pp.tags -> 'building:min_level' AS "building:min_level", pp.tags -> 'note' AS "note", pp."source:geometry:entity", pp."source:geometry:date", pp."source:geometry:oidn", pp."source:geometry", pp."source:geometry:uidn", pp.source, pp.fixme, lp."H_DTM_MIN", lp."H_DTM_GEM", lp."H_DSM_MAX", lp."H_DSM_P99", lp."HN_MAX", lp."HN_P99" , ST_AsGeoJSON(ST_Transform(pp.way,900913),15,0) AS geojson  FROM planet_osm_polygon pp LEFT JOIN lidar_polygon lp ON ( lp."source:geometry:oidn" = pp."source:geometry:oidn" AND lp."source:geometry:entity" = pp."source:geometry:entity" )  WHERE pp.way && ST_SetSRID('BOX3D(345648.241905567 6615319.049968861, 345801.11596213735 6615471.924025433)'::box3d, 900913) AND pp.building IS NOT NULL AND pp.highway IS NULL

```

Mon, Dec 27, 2021, 17:59:24 - @gplv2:matrix.org: ik vrees dat een officiele lijst van vertaalde straten niet direct te verkrijgen is.  Natuurlijk wel goed als je moescroen in orde krijgt zo, wij doen in OSM niet aan taalpolemiek noch politiek, hoe meer informatie hoe beter de map.   Maar ik denk dat we best niet beginnen met formaat "fr - nl" aan te houden in die gemeentes, zeker niet met fr eerst in vlaamse en vice versa.   Over brussel zijn we allemaal vrij akkoord hoe we dat opgelost hebben.   "addr:street:nl" en "addr:street:fr" tags zijn prima, maar voor de rest zou ik "addr:street" de primaire taal van die gemeente laten staan

Tue, Dec 28, 2021, 21:28:43 - @gplv2:matrix.org: <@lepirlouit2:matrix.org "graag wat inlichtingen ivm het m..."> trappen in OSM zijn lines, in GRB zijn dit polygons die op de oppervlakte slagen, in OSM zijn dit logische paden waardoor er routes kunnen gebruik van maken.  omdat in GRB de orientatie niet gekend is kan deze niet automatisch omgezet worden , er werd verwacht van de mapper van dit aan te pakken maar het is gebleken dat deze vaak as-is werden geupload.   Vandaar dat hier een beetje consensus is van die te wissen uit de bron.

In chrome heb je wss een ander gebied getest.   Ik was net de filter aan het bekijken om die versie van urbis in te bouwen als ik zag dat het stopte.

> 	3713790 records
> 	613649 busnrs
> 	2707398 housenumbers
> 
> Strange stuff:
> 	1405 streets didn't match with only 1 postcode
> 
> Integrity check:
> 	0 streetnames didn't match their streetname-id
> 	0 streets didn't match with only 1 municipality
> 	0 municipality-names didn't match their NIS-code
> 	0 postcodes didn't match to 1 single municipality
> 	0 addresses were identical on postcode, street and housenumber, but have different NIS-codes
> 	7897 addresses have one or more busnrs as well as one or more apptnrs

Mon, Jan 3, 2022, 16:08:24 - @gplv2:matrix.org: For PICC/ Wallonia around the borders I actually keep the addr:postal_code OSM data.  But I do delete addr:city on every building because that's useless, and addr:country I delete because it's plain silly
Mon, Jan 3, 2022, 16:12:42 - @gplv2:matrix.org: What I noticed too,  grbtool glues whatever it can together when you export, so adjacent buildings that share a wall, those points are merged normally.   but it has a threshold on the margin, meaning the geometry cannot change too much just for the sake of gluing them together.   For GRB that seemed to work usually fine, but for PICC, the seem to be less accurate between buildings, so sometimes that doesn't work.  And then simplify will erase the node on one of the buildings because it thinks it is useless.

So I end up joining and merging points a lot.   The validator does pick it up.  
Mon, Jan 3, 2022, 16:15:23 - @gplv2:matrix.org: I raised the GRB vector activation resolution, so we can export more at once, but the downside is that it's quite heavy on the database because it contains double of the data now and it's also heavier on the browser as there are more vectors.

Thu, Jan 6, 2022, 14:17:57 - @gplv2:matrix.org: OMG
Thu, Jan 6, 2022, 14:18:39 - @gplv2:matrix.org: <@stijn_claes:matrix.org "Omdat het de Edgard Tinellaan is..."> hiet in Mechelen is dat gewoon DE Tinellaan !  merci voor de obvious te staten ;-)
Fri, Jan 7, 2022, 16:37:51 - @gplv2:matrix.org: FYI: I've improved the GRBTOOL post-analyse job on the data.   I've noticed that Picc data has a lot of inaccuracies ,  there are a number of problems that made it really hard to migrate data to OSM without having to fix a zillion problems.  Every export I did of a decent area brings up about 80 warnings and a good number of errors when validating in JOSM.  The following issues where a challenge to address properly:
- many geometries slightly cross eachother.  in the GRB data that is quite different, almost everything is properly attached
- Picc has overlapping objects.  Older versions of the same house get an update but also a different unique ID.   This should not happen but it does.   Often 2 geometries where 1 has a much worse measurements and the 'newer' has better measurements.
- Picc has crossing objects, which is not the same as overlapping,   overlaps are easier to handle than crossings.

The solution has been to add a lot more post-processing after the data loaded, in fact, it's done as pre-processing before exporting.  The following has been added:  2 checkboxes (default off, for testing purposes) that do a number of tasks in this order , they have stupid names at the moment but I'll explain what they do in the background:

(the second checkbox Remove non-relations duplicates (beta!)  does this :)
- first all overlaps are analysed to find objects that fully overlap.  A comparison is made between the properties of the object, the date is taken as lead to decide which one of the 2 is bad.  In almost all cases that is the oldest one.  But I discovered that there are objects that are newer and are obviously wrong as well.   In those cases , the addressing data is taken into account, if one object has that information, the other one has not, then the correct one is the oldest geometry/building.
- secondly at the same time there is also an analysis on overlapping buildings, in case the overlap is ( currently set at) more than 0.5% then the logic kicks in action to decide which one of the 2 needs to be filtered out.
- Existing Multipolygons are excluded here, they don't happen a lot and are very hard to decide what to remove/keep/not touch.

This is all done to prepare for the 2nd and third stage (this 3rd is checkbox:  Perform mapshaper clean on shapes (beta!) )
the 2nd stage is always done:
- simplify the ways, remove extra nodes,so it cleans up the shapes and tries to keep as much of the original shape intact.  Some circles have hundreds of nodes and can be represented with a lot less.   The simplify is set at 90% now, tests have shown me that that is a very good setting at the moment).

This is all done to prepare for the final 3rd stage , and the one that takes care of almost all errors/warnings you'll see in JOSM when unprocessed.
- third is a mapshaper.clean.   It will compensate for the small/subtle differences in measurements that prevent objects from being attached to eachother where they should.  For this to work properly,  1st and 2nd stage are crucial to pre-prepare the data so that clean doesn't create MultiPolygons from overlaps/crossings.

The results is this , when exporting data without any checkbox, you pretty much get them raw (but simplified) with plenty of JOSM work to fix, attach, join points and merge points work.  quite timeconsuming.

with just the 1st stage options, overlapping buildings and crossed buildings are tackled.  But that just takes care of JOSM validation errors and a few warnings (but it prepares the data very well for 3d).

I tend to make it do everything and offer opt-outs for people who thinks it's messed something up.   You can see the difference when loading up the data in JOSM without the boxes ticked, and then : "Remove non-relations duplicates (beta!)" ticket, and then a layer with "Perform mapshaper clean on shapes (beta!) " ticked.   Doing mapshaper without the other button will give you very crappy results, not good.  So don't look at mapshaper clean output without the other one ticked.

Doing all this kinda makes the data from Picc have more GRB-like quality.   In all of this I have not tested the Urbis data , I still have to validate this stuff for Urbis.  For GRB it doesn't seem to make a huge difference, but it won't hurt either.

If you want to see the difference, just export the 3 versions and run josm validate directly on the exported layer and see the huge difference in errors and warnings.
Fri, Jan 7, 2022, 16:45:37 - @gplv2:matrix.org: You can check with some test data here :
- raw  :https://grbosm.site/public/b8252bb47fc61f7edd8e1673c0e7bed6.osm
- overlap/crossings removed : https://grbosm.site/public/99a90da944c6d218f20a2fec193a3552.osm
- previous + clean/normalised: https://grbosm.site/public/00ca0f170c791887941e27d4ac8a0560.osm

Open each in JOSM and validate , use the first to see where the issues are, zoom to selected element, and then switch to the other 2 to see what happened.

Sun, Jan 9, 2022, 17:36:00 - @gplv2:matrix.org: Just a little headsup on housenumbers in GRB/CRAB.   I'm doing my own town here , which I put most of the buildings on myself before the tool came and I notice that there are wrong housenumbers assigned sometimes.   Pay good attentions to adjecent buildings having the same housenumber.  JOSM warns you about that, so merging geometries should be done with care.  You need to use some logic, whenever a housenumber is lacking in the row , like OSM has 138 , 140 , 142  and GRB has 138, 138, 142 for the same houses, you can be sure that GRB/CRAB is wrong there and the middle is for sure 140.
Sun, Jan 9, 2022, 17:38:48 - joost_schouppe: GRB is wrong, but not CRAB. 95% of cases like this. Typical conversion errors from crab to GRB. I gave up even reporting them, as all the underlying data is correct. It's just a translation table AIV manages somewhere that has errors
Sun, Jan 9, 2022, 17:40:16 - joost_schouppe: Whenever you have cases like this, look at CRAB. Now, CRAB of course has errors too, and they might look similar. A recent one I saw was a whole row, starting with 20-22 on one house, and after 38 a house without a number. Turned out all of these numbers needed to be shifted one house to the side
Sun, Jan 9, 2022, 17:40:33 - @gplv2:matrix.org: yea, think you're right, I kinda slammed them both together

Thu, Jan 13, 2022, 17:36:14 - @gplv2:matrix.org: > While google does not provide data without any services attached it does clearly provide replacement products and competes with the OSM ecosystem as a whole. It would be naive to not recognize that. That doesn't mean we can't accept support and data from them, but it shouldn't be in a form that restricts our freedom going forward over what we have agreed upon as a core property of the project (in this case that we provide our data on open terms).
> 
> During the licence change we had to negotiate with, in some cases unhappy, third parties in exactly that situation (Nearmap comes to mind, but there were others). Regardless of how amicable a relationship was at one point in time, we need to recognize that things change and flexibility that was there at one time might go away.
> 
> Simon

Thu, Jan 13, 2022, 17:44:55 - @gplv2:matrix.org: but if you need the RAW data
Thu, Jan 13, 2022, 17:45:08 - @gplv2:matrix.org: switch all that stuff off, then you get how it's in de postgis database
Thu, Jan 13, 2022, 17:47:41 - @gplv2:matrix.org: it's good when you want to delve into that stuff like here, but don't use those for importing, as the 'cured' versions I make will often fix 80 warnings in Josm vs. the raw data.   It will attach adjacent buildings, simplify , take care of overnodig, and prevent relations being created from some exotic combinations of those overlaying buildings,  it will glue those seperate buildings together.   Only thing you do have to do in josm is sometimes take care of duplicate addresses on the same house that is made of parts in Picc, they address all/most parts in Pic db
Thu, Jan 13, 2022, 17:48:46 - @gplv2:matrix.org: and I can't automatically clean those.   as it's the same in cities when buildings touch ,  but it's better to delete 2 tags than to fix 80 geo's

Thu, Jan 13, 2022, 18:00:30 - @gplv2:matrix.org: I found a pretty awesome function
Thu, Jan 13, 2022, 18:00:38 - @gplv2:matrix.org: ```
localhost:5434 grb-data@grb_api=> select pb.osm_id,po.osm_id,pb.tags->'ref:UrbIS',ST_HausdorffDistance(po.way,pb.way)  from planet_osm_polygon po JOIN planet_building_polygon pb ON ST_Overlaps(po.way,pb.way) WHERE pb.osm_id=225176766;
  osm_id   |  osm_id  | ?column? | st_hausdorffdistance 
-----------+----------+----------+----------------------
 225176766 | 79414002 | [null]   | 0.004402572134020643
 225176766 | 79413944 | [null]   |    25.65860039906734
```

Thu, Jan 13, 2022, 18:01:42 - @gplv2:matrix.org: this is the test building : https://www.openstreetmap.org/way/225176766
Thu, Jan 13, 2022, 18:01:55 - @gplv2:matrix.org: the left OSM id is the offical one, the right is my internal one
Thu, Jan 13, 2022, 18:02:26 - @gplv2:matrix.org: it's compairing a copy of belgium OSM data imported as is for building=* algorithm
Thu, Jan 13, 2022, 18:02:41 - @gplv2:matrix.org: against the (R side) which is GRB/PICC/URBIS data
Thu, Jan 13, 2022, 18:03:20 - @gplv2:matrix.org: that number says how equal they are, because of minumum difference we can't do an equal
Thu, Jan 13, 2022, 18:03:36 - @gplv2:matrix.org: but the cutoff between it's neighbor is big
Thu, Jan 13, 2022, 18:03:42 - @gplv2:matrix.org: 0.004402572134020643 vs 25.xxx
Thu, Jan 13, 2022, 18:04:18 - @gplv2:matrix.org: so once I can ID the buildings and match in both database, I can calculate how truly equal it is without a spatial join, which is very fast.
Thu, Jan 13, 2022, 18:04:43 - joost_schouppe: Pieter built something similar with GRB data IIRC 
Thu, Jan 13, 2022, 18:04:52 - @gplv2:matrix.org: I'm writing a node program that adapts the JOSM datafile directly and adds the source tags
Thu, Jan 13, 2022, 18:07:29 - @gplv2:matrix.org: <@joost_schouppe:matrix.org "Pieter built something similar w..."> yea, I have that stuff also built in GRBtool, but not for this goal, this is to tackle the wild imports.  it takes a lot of time to do this manually and for what goals.  merging buildings that match exactly is cucumbersome in JOSM, so I'm going to use the database to detect area's where this is a problem, open the area in josm, run the tool that mods the osm diff file locally and then validate/check and upload without touching the geometries, then later on the tool will filter those out.  I will also add address data when it's missing while doing so. 
Thu, Jan 13, 2022, 18:08:05 - @gplv2:matrix.org: and to tackle Urbis import, which is essentially the same problem except I can use ref:UrbIS to match easily.
Thu, Jan 13, 2022, 18:11:13 - @gplv2:matrix.org: you'll see that Brussels will become a lot more manageable and the tool will work a lot better to achieve the goal.  I understand the wild imports to a point, people want to see buildings, but they just never thought about the aspect of time and changes in time and being able to manage those.  When you see how fast I created 30K+ buildings, I think the goal of completing belgium will be much more closer than ever.

Thu, Jan 13, 2022, 19:26:32 - @gplv2:matrix.org: I can't automate it all (I can but it would not be accurate).  The default with conflicts is to do the best when we're 100% sure, but when in doubt or not able to determine, it's up to the mapper to solve those edge cases and complete, the tool is there to assist as much as it can, but the mapper is the one that does the thinking that requires neural networking :)

Thu, Jan 13, 2022, 20:23:09 - @gplv2:matrix.org: so it doesn't detect the intersection.  it's like with adjacent buildings when you move up to complete at your edge.
Thu, Jan 13, 2022, 20:24:07 - @gplv2:matrix.org: if one is aware of this  , it will popup in josm validation and then you see it's there
Thu, Jan 13, 2022, 20:24:17 - @gplv2:matrix.org: it's one of the reasons I recommend using my mapcss
Thu, Jan 13, 2022, 20:24:27 - @gplv2:matrix.org: there you can see white text : existing import
Thu, Jan 13, 2022, 20:24:35 - @gplv2:matrix.org: yellow : new version

Thu, Jan 13, 2022, 22:36:39 - pietervdvn: I havent' been following the converstations here in great detail (was a bit too much to read it all)
However, it seems like buidlings in Brussels have 'ref:urbis=<nnn>' whereas the import tool uses 'source:geometry:ref=urbis/<nnn>'. How do we deal with this?
Thu, Jan 13, 2022, 22:43:26 - @gplv2:matrix.org: <@joost_schouppe:matrix.org "Imma download a dump myself and ..."> we need a user manual
Thu, Jan 13, 2022, 23:09:40 - @gplv2:matrix.org: it's already discussed a bit here , but the gist is this:   There was a single flat import of Urbis done at one point in the past.   They backreferenced with `ref:UrbIS` , but since then, the official way is `source:geometry:*` namespace.  The issue with Urbis is that they don't keep track of modification dates like Picc/GRB do.

Urbis uses a version number instead , but unfortunately that wasn't imported when it was done.  So tracking changes based on version nr bumps is not possible.  GRBTool supports that version number as `source:geometry:version=%d` .   the unique ID should not change with each modification in none of the datasets.   In theory.  In reality I do see that sometimes buildings get a new number.  I don't know the circumstances this happens, but it's safe to think along the lines of :  rebuilding, restauration with significant differences in structure outlines, think terraces, roofs, overhangs, and so on.  not to mention:  User mistakes at the source.  It doesn't happen that often but it does.

So back to urbis, I shown a spread of the version numbers here earlier, seems that version=6 is the most widely used one.  so assuming when there is no version number that the version is 1 only takes care of about 10K buildings.   which is not a lot.   The `ref:UrbIS` is actually supported by GRBtool in absence of `source:geometry:ref`.  I think it's needless to say we want the same system to backreference for future updates and to keep track of changes, while at the same time we don't want to throw away what is in there.

I've thought this through the last 2 weeks and I came up with the solution I think will solve that problem for the most part,  I'm writing a tool to do comparisons of the geometries of all buildings in belgium that aren't tagged but who are obviously efforts of individuals using the shape files and making a solo effort of introducing buildings.   It must be a hell of a job to keep doing that tbh.   And the probem of tracking updates is still a problem, people make slight changes, attach nodes, stretch here and there for minor corrections, we can't compare in an exact way.

So what we need (assuming the geometries are pretty much ok imported, which from all I can see is pretty much the case) is to have these source tags added without touching the geometries.

we can do this with :
```
osm_id   |  osm_id(internal)  | ?column? | st_hausdorffdistance 
-----------+----------+----------+----------------------
 225176766 | 79414002 | [null]   | 0.004402572134020643
 225176766 | 79413944 | [null]   |    25.65860039906734
```

the concept works, so I compare GRB/Picc/URbis buildings with their OSM counterparts, you see the difference above here , a nice cutoff where the low number means we have a match.  the left osm_id you can look up, it's the official one.  The building has been imported and never touched since then geometry-wise.

So for URbis, we need to add the version and the `source:geometry:ref`, even though ref:UrbIS is present, it's not always correct anymore but we can't change it to the correct one, when we correct, we need the former to be added, which will take priority.  But this will also work in for example Namur where tons of buildings come from the Picc shape files directly.   I don't want to throw away that work by just flatout merging everything, doing double work and so on.   In the end we'll have nice differences which we can bring to the foreground using the filters (and also external programs like MapComplete will then be able to spot those.

I'm pretty much halfway coding this,  it will make mods directly in OSM/JOSM diff format , I'll review them and send the uploads, that will not be so much work when I organise this system.  but we'll not touch the geometries at all.  Just the tags.   In GRB there are also imports done by people that didn't want to wait for a structured approach, and we'll take care of those imports as well and bring them under "version control".

This all is born out of many idea's I had but everytime I looked at the data left and right, it wasn't good enough or error prone.  It's the exceptions that are a problem but it's better to have to manually review 10% of an export of a BXL area instead of having to merge/migrate 100% just to get the source tags in the database, I tried some areas in brussels and it's truly not feasible to do this.   So we'll not throw away ref:UrbIS (mind the 2 capitals at the end, that got me while coding) , we'll use it but its so outdated sometimes that we have to flag differences there, but that's the idea behind the tool, to filter the work and draw attention to the things that need it.
Thu, Jan 13, 2022, 23:22:28 - pietervdvn: Phew, that is a long gist. Mc does already do building comparisons, we can partly automate that there and I used to have a tool to do this conflation (which I ran on Bruges a few years back).
Thu, Jan 13, 2022, 23:22:42 - @gplv2:matrix.org: yes but you do them building by building
Thu, Jan 13, 2022, 23:23:24 - pietervdvn: <@gplv2:matrix.org "yes but you do them building by ..."> For now, yes. That can be scripted and automated
Thu, Jan 13, 2022, 23:23:26 - @gplv2:matrix.org: <@pietervdvn:matrix.org "Phew, that is a long gist. Mc do..."> it's a long problem too
Thu, Jan 13, 2022, 23:23:46 - @gplv2:matrix.org: <@pietervdvn:matrix.org "For now, yes. That can be script..."> but that's not how buildings are stored in OSM
Thu, Jan 13, 2022, 23:24:58 - @gplv2:matrix.org: many are attached to eachother and there is overlap, but also from the "neighbors". so overlap doesn't tell the whole story.    
Thu, Jan 13, 2022, 23:25:00 - pietervdvn: ?
Thu, Jan 13, 2022, 23:25:44 - pietervdvn: Oh, yes, i know. The conflation currently somewhat deals with that too
Thu, Jan 13, 2022, 23:25:55 - pietervdvn: But far from perfect though
Thu, Jan 13, 2022, 23:26:00 - @gplv2:matrix.org: to analyse correctly you need an area of buildings to analyse and when joined they share the nodes.  And that's not always how the source data is structured in Picc
Thu, Jan 13, 2022, 23:26:47 - pietervdvn: Oh, right
Thu, Jan 13, 2022, 23:26:57 - @gplv2:matrix.org: that's why I do so many postprocessing, I know it's difficult to do this as you say.  it's also even for people using JOSM a tedious and difficult job to start merging and joining
Thu, Jan 13, 2022, 23:27:50 - @gplv2:matrix.org: so the postprocessing I wrote most recently finally takes care of that, btw in GRB they are already merged and share nodes for the most part, so this issue didn't arise until Picc came ... into the picture
Thu, Jan 13, 2022, 23:29:08 - @gplv2:matrix.org: but MapComplete is great to fill in a few gaps, I can imagine the functions and libraries (we both use) needed to make that work and glueing a building in somewhere building per building is a good solution in my book 
Thu, Jan 13, 2022, 23:32:05 - @gplv2:matrix.org: what I also noticed for example is that in Picc, the addresses are often put on different parts belonging to the same building, the equivalent in having addresses on Gbg and Gba entity in GRB data.  But GRB only puts addresses on the Gbg ones.  Picc doesn't do that.  It has addresses on both and doesn't distinct in their source data what it is : so no roof vs house.  Just in osm pseudo: building=yes and building=yes where the smaller part is the roof, or the GRB equivalent of : 'verdieping'
Thu, Jan 13, 2022, 23:33:55 - @gplv2:matrix.org: and that problem you don't notice until you work in an area with all entities present and tapping the 'validate' button.   I actually delete addresses from part when I'm sure they are redundant.  But it's hard to distinguish that in a row of 'gesloten bebouwing' vs the free standing villa with 3 different parts.      
Thu, Jan 13, 2022, 23:35:39 - @gplv2:matrix.org: I know that wasn't really a true gist,and I'm leaving out already many details and issues I've encountered and dealt with, the boundaries are quite troublesome with overlapping sets, that was the very long interaction between me and joost_schouppe about.   But it's through those that I learn a lot about the source data.

Thu, Jan 20, 2022, 16:18:23 - @gplv2:matrix.org: <@Seppe:matrix.org "Je kan twee gebouwen die netjes ..."> Gebruik de validator.   Vaak heeft die de juiste twee geselecteerd, je moet wel opletten dat 2 gebouwen naast elkaar niet geselecteerd zijn,  je kan bij het mergen zien dat hij verkeerd selecteert wanneer je een merge conflict krijgt op de source:geometry:ref , even cancelen.   Ik gebruik de validator, en ik werk meestal van onder naar boven de lijst af, de errors zijn vaak gevolg van de warnings, duplicate points bijvoorbeeld is laatste dat je moet nazien  (zit een autofix in).  Wanneer alle warnings weggewerkt zijn kan je die aanpakken.   In de validator kan je zoom-to-problem doen waardoor je visueel kan zien of hij de juiste selecteert.   Ik gebruik bijna exclusief de validator window voor het selecteren

It's not the same streets, the addresses on both side also include the full name with fr - nl present in order to match against the associatedStreet relation and the building addresses (who have double names too )

Sun, Jan 23, 2022, 20:07:24 - @gplv2:matrix.org: afaik for streets with 4 names (2 on each) :   `name  =   name:left:fr - name:left:nl  / name:right:fr - name:right:nl`  , that's kind of the principle used to determine final combined name tag.   For the https://www.openstreetmap.org/way/23160791 the logic still is correct as it only has 3 names :  `name = name:left:fr - name:left:nl / name:nl`  .  Since the border there is VL , there is no second name for that part, so the logic is still correct.  The only consideration left is should we repeat the FR name when for both sides it's the same.   That's a consensus we need to aggree upon.   
Sun, Jan 23, 2022, 20:09:17 - @gplv2:matrix.org: btw, I use left/right here without checking the actual street, they might have to be interchanged there.  but it's the principle I use
Sun, Jan 23, 2022, 20:18:20 - @gplv2:matrix.org: think I typed a mistake should be for Woluwestraat : `name = name:left:fr - name:left:nl / name:right`
Sun, Jan 23, 2022, 20:18:44 - @gplv2:matrix.org: bloody confusing the deeper I think :)
Sun, Jan 23, 2022, 20:20:02 - @bxl-forever:multimob.be: Fine, we‚Äôll try to follow that convention as from now.  I like it.
Next on my list: updating this page of the wiki: https://wiki.openstreetmap.org/wiki/Multilingual_names#Combination_with_name:left.3D.2A_and_name:right.3D.2A
Sun, Jan 23, 2022, 20:22:47 - @gplv2:matrix.org: They do ask not to overload the name tag too much in the wiki, hence why I'm not totally happy with it myself, but the way I construct the name tag is I start you with all the name:left name:left:nl tags and so on, and then at the end, it's clear how 'many' we need to use to construct it, I never start with deciding on the name tag itself, I sort out the relations, I see the streetname on the buildings in the source data and from there we end up with  X number of associated relations.    It's kind of organic process, looking what is there and then using the same logic all the time
Sun, Jan 23, 2022, 20:24:14 - @gplv2:matrix.org: I'm actually a fan again of the associatedStreet relations for these problems.   I have a love/hate relationship with them, lots of mappers don't update them when they add adddressed buildings , which makes them prone to be incomplete
Sun, Jan 23, 2022, 20:43:54 - @gplv2:matrix.org: I'll update brussels with the urbis refs further the comming weeks, when that's done, you'll notice the GRBtool will be much more usefull,  Many simple buildings that are traced also match, I think the level (0.3 Hausdorf) is pretty strict, I could raise it to 0.5, It would match a lot more but problem is that for really simple squares it's a bit of a too-loose match.  For complicated geometries it's pretty good but I noticed some matches with threshold 0.5 are not visually too great.  But so far , this program seems to work as I want it.  It will also automatically put a note on ref:UrbIS that don't match with the current Urbis data anymore, which is really useful when a mapper with local knowledge knows what happened.   So be aware of notes.  I also put fixme:* in there but I resolve each one of them before upload.   It's a helper tag for me while rpocessing the data.   Unless there is something really conflicting , then I leave them and upload as-is.

Tue, Jan 25, 2022, 18:41:38 - @gplv2:matrix.org: What really should happen is perceived mistakes should be coupled to Urbis, so that they can get the communities to work on sorting it out, checking the legal documents etc.  That is the only way to break that chain, because honestly..  if the official data source doesn't have the correct names....  how can we trust the rest ? You probably only notice the ones you think is wrong but I assure you, I have fixed a lot more than those few.  So let's put it on the table and try to get aggreement on the correct spelling.

Thu, Jan 27, 2022, 22:02:33 - gpoilvet: with the validator that it shows in yellow when it overlaps
Thu, Jan 27, 2022, 22:03:30 - @gplv2:matrix.org: so I never have to really select both houses, the validator does that but you need to look really good because it sometimes uses 2 houses since the intersect, then I just take the next selection as there are multiple warnings on the same overlaps (2 + 2 ) , but they overlap with eachother too, so you get like 3 or 4 warnings
Thu, Jan 27, 2022, 22:03:46 - @gplv2:matrix.org: 2 of those are good ones, and when you solve those 2, the others will be gone next validation
Thu, Jan 27, 2022, 22:03:56 - @gplv2:matrix.org: so when I fix stuff, I validate often 
Thu, Jan 27, 2022, 22:04:29 - @gplv2:matrix.org: in some cases you'll need to do it manually, but I do 90% of merging in the validator window and it's features
Thu, Jan 27, 2022, 22:04:49 - @gplv2:matrix.org: it's a LOT less clicking

Thu, Jan 27, 2022, 22:06:37 - @gplv2:matrix.org: I work bottom to top
Thu, Jan 27, 2022, 22:06:41 - @gplv2:matrix.org: in the validator
Thu, Jan 27, 2022, 22:06:55 - @gplv2:matrix.org: when you fix warnings
Thu, Jan 27, 2022, 22:07:04 - @gplv2:matrix.org: often the errors are fixed as well
Thu, Jan 27, 2022, 22:07:08 - @gplv2:matrix.org: duplicate points etc.
Thu, Jan 27, 2022, 22:07:38 - @gplv2:matrix.org: when you fix those, (there is a automatic fix for that), it makes it hard as you now have duplicate ways since the points got merged.
Thu, Jan 27, 2022, 22:07:47 - @gplv2:matrix.org: so I always work to the top from the bottom warning
Thu, Jan 27, 2022, 22:08:49 - @gplv2:matrix.org: after a while you'll understand if you can do the other way around here and there, but I stick to that system because it's the least work , the inverse can often make it more complicated

Sat, Jan 29, 2022, 17:40:52 - @gplv2:matrix.org: In fact I first thought you used a wrong relationtype, I changed it in multipolygon in JOSM, then I started to wonder, does a building relation exists, I never heard of it, I don't think it exists for a long time, or was common like 5 to 15 years ago. It works really good tbh, better than I thought, but it's still young and XML is really truly awefull to handle in most languages.

Thu, Feb 3, 2022, 01:07:38 - @gplv2:matrix.org: backreferencing.   de datum zal veranderen als het gebouw verandert of opnieuw en beter opgemeten wordt.  Dus https://buildings.osm.be tool gaat dat dan zien en die nieuwe data exporteren om te vergelijken en te updaten.  Deze houden de link bidirectioneel met brondata.   Als je dat niet doet dan heb je enkel gebouwen staan en die updaten zal nooit echt gebeuren omdat je door het bos de bomen niet meer ziet of door de bomen het bos.  Er zijn veel voordelen aan, geen enkel nadeel.
Thu, Feb 3, 2022, 01:11:37 - @gplv2:matrix.org: <@gpoilvet:matrix.org "ja ik ben al een tijd bezig met ..."> dat was een algemene opmerking van mij, ik zie dat overal, en in uw streek valt het nog heel goed mee, vaak is het ook JOSM die snap doet naar een lijn en is het onbewust, het is wel vaak gepruts om dat goed te trekken.  Net die area eens gematcht met GRB en tags geupdate.  Je hebt 713 buildings daar zo accuraat gemapt dat ze matchen met het toch strakke Hausdorf algortitme dat ik gebruik.  ik heb daar 1147 buildings gematcht, 1468 misses.  Pieter komt op nr 2 met 429 stuks .   Dat zijn dus 1147 buildings en adressen die gematcht zijn en niet meer gemerged moeten worden met grb brondata.   de tool die ik nu gebruik is wel de enige die de tags net niet gebruikt omdat die spatial matches doet met de geometries, maar daarvoor is  hij dus ook gemaakt.

Thu, Feb 3, 2022, 17:15:54 - @gplv2:matrix.org: het is trouwens het beste om eerst de warnings op te lossen en dan naar errors te gaan dan andersom bij GRB merge werk,  omdat vaak als je de warning oplost de error is opgelost.   (duplicate points bv, bij errors is vaak indicatie dat er meer aan de hand is).  Dus los van onder naar boven op en dat scheelt.   zeker als je autofix krijgt op de errors over duplicates dan wijst dat op een dieper probleem,  als je dan autofix gebruikt (bij de errors), dan krijg je nog meer fouten bij de warnings.

Fri, Feb 4, 2022, 17:29:06 - @gplv2:matrix.org: <@joost_schouppe:matrix.org "Yep, goes to show that no datase..."> OSM is better because the mapper is sitting between source and target and that has been my point of view from day one.  If GRB was perfect we could just import mechanically and go to bed.   That's why dealing with small chunks and reviewing them is what adds the value.  I can only treat the data as best as I can and try to automate the stuff, use fixme's to point out to the mapper where there is an issue but in the end, it's the mapper that makes the difference.   btw, he has mapped streetlights as well , so cool.

Fri, Feb 4, 2022, 20:11:14 - jarnoo: Speaking of GRB, it seems all buildings I import stem from a 2018 version of it, with hither and thither bits from 2020 and 2021. One such case where current GRB and imagery differ from the import, was https://www.openstreetmap.org/way/1026520453. In the import it missed a corner which was added in 2019, while current GRB shows it correctly.

Sun, Feb 6, 2022, 21:11:49 - @gplv2:matrix.org: We need some kind of feedback loop, especially PICC has more issues than the rest but I see errors in all datasets, I'm thinking about setting up an API endpoint as well, but that means having a way to flag a certain building 
Sun, Feb 6, 2022, 21:14:01 - @gplv2:matrix.org: I would rather just offer the data, if they (urbis/picc/grb) don't want to use it, it's fine but I see issues along the way of mappers replacing geometries that were good.   I think we need to set something like note:grb up but It's not easy to have bidirectional checks in place
Sun, Feb 6, 2022, 21:15:11 - @gplv2:matrix.org: my goal is : prevent and export of a certain building, marked as : not ok.  it needs to be machine parseable 
Sun, Feb 6, 2022, 21:17:02 - @gplv2:matrix.org: so in the tool, I would probably have to add a way to mark it, send the results to the API which then will keep track of those, they also need to survive a new data-import , which when done by ref would not be too hard.  But we probably also need to introduce a flag in OSM as well, like note:grb .  I could just use the existence of that tag as an indicator to leave it alone.
Sun, Feb 6, 2022, 21:17:38 - @gplv2:matrix.org: <@gplv2:matrix.org "my goal is : prevent and export ..."> so preventing export means preventing a merge/import of it to be more clear
Sun, Feb 6, 2022, 21:19:50 - @gplv2:matrix.org: I regularly import belgium into the GRBtool, when I update that, the auto-building gets better, when someone changes landuse/corrects it, the algo will become better, I can do this seperately from the data import, it's a second database which is used when the user gets the vector layer, so it's dynamic and not pre-determined.

Thu, Feb 10, 2022, 12:36:59 - gpoilvet: <@joost_schouppe:matrix.org "Doubleclick on "lid van multipol..."> found it!
Thu, Feb 10, 2022, 12:37:18 - @gplv2:matrix.org: it's the fact that it IS a relation that is the problem, and I did everything I could to detect those but in this case, I suspect they share this 1 little node and I can't fix that using formulas and pre/post processing.  because it's identical to separate buildings that are next to eachother
Thu, Feb 10, 2022, 12:38:16 - gpoilvet sent an image. (Media omitted)
Thu, Feb 10, 2022, 12:38:29 - gpoilvet: how do i handle it?üòÖ
Thu, Feb 10, 2022, 12:39:37 - joost_schouppe: Copy the tags, then delete the whole thing 
Thu, Feb 10, 2022, 12:40:05 - @gplv2:matrix.org: if they would overlap, and each building had it's own tags I would have fixed the overlap automatically, but here it's in the source data,   when transforming data it takes many steps, in each step a problem is handled so some overlaps don't become a relation , but when it's already a multipolygon in the source, it stays one as each member doesn't have it's own tags .   And this multipolygon (= relation in OSM) is actually not a valid OSM relation
Thu, Feb 10, 2022, 12:41:02 - @gplv2:matrix.org: so it might be valid in GRB but not valid in OSM, often it's some kind of drawing mistake in whatever tool the source uses
Thu, Feb 10, 2022, 12:43:04 - @gplv2:matrix.org: neerstraat 54 is a bit the same, but since it's not just 1 node, it's indeed a building and not a relation
Thu, Feb 10, 2022, 12:44:13 - @gplv2:matrix.org: it's a garage
Thu, Feb 10, 2022, 12:44:36 - @gplv2:matrix.org: the solution in this case would be: just duplicate the tags.
Thu, Feb 10, 2022, 12:44:57 - @gplv2:matrix.org: remove the relation, and copy the source tags on both,  it's not a problem having duplicate tags present.
Thu, Feb 10, 2022, 12:45:17 - @gplv2:matrix.org: but make them 2 buildings, 1 house, 1 garage
Thu, Feb 10, 2022, 12:46:09 - @gplv2:matrix.org: and put the address information on the house only
Thu, Feb 10, 2022, 12:48:30 - @gplv2:matrix.org: that's why doing your own pre-processing on the export layer is a good idea,  you can use JOSM validator on the export too.  when I see a relation in the export I always give it some attention before I merge it, to see if it's legit one (eg. having an outer and an inner poly)
Thu, Feb 10, 2022, 12:51:45 - @gplv2:matrix.org: it's also sometimes possible that the source data is causing the transformation to a relation in those data processing steps in very rare cases.  But I did manage to lower the number of relations with factor 10 by my estimates.  it's more of a problem in PICC due to it being less accurate (cm scale) than in GRB but it happens on all of them

While midgards is very optimal for addressing.

Thu, Feb 10, 2022, 16:57:19 - @gplv2:matrix.org: yea

Thu, Feb 10, 2022, 16:58:12 - @gplv2:matrix.org: so overlaps picc-picc but also overlap picc-grb
Thu, Feb 10, 2022, 16:58:24 - joost_schouppe: <@gplv2:matrix.org "overlap GRB - > picc  ?  wtf"> right - would be nice to know why they don't stick to their own land :D
Thu, Feb 10, 2022, 16:58:25 - @gplv2:matrix.org: probably urbis as well
Thu, Feb 10, 2022, 16:58:46 - @gplv2:matrix.org: <@joost_schouppe:matrix.org "right - would be nice to know wh..."> yea, if you want to divide the nation up, don't do it half-assed
Thu, Feb 10, 2022, 17:01:23 - @gplv2:matrix.org: probably also valid:  2 measuremens of the same building, that should be a new version, but they end up in PICc having a different unique ID, according to their docs, that should not happen.   The date should change, the geometry too but not the unique identifier that is supposed to exist as long as the building exists.  That is at the core of the overlap problem within the same dataset.   They are in fact considered 2 different buildings, they just happen to totally be on top of eachother
Thu, Feb 10, 2022, 17:02:39 - joost_schouppe: <@gplv2:matrix.org "probably also valid:  2 measurem..."> so you're saying "whenever there is two buildings on top of each other, they also have two different unique identifiers - which makes no sense"?
Thu, Feb 10, 2022, 17:03:14 - @gplv2:matrix.org: with some modded code I can probably push those back into the API from the clients when he's exporting the layer they get detected.  So I can do some automatic flagging there.   the more I think and hear, the more I feel we need to get this feedback system in place soon
Thu, Feb 10, 2022, 17:07:37 - @gplv2:matrix.org: <@joost_schouppe:matrix.org "so you're saying "whenever there..."> no not really true.  Because sometimes they just cross and 1 doesn't totally contain the other, but due to inaccuracies in measuring this also happens for legit buildings just next to eachother.  But I do detect those that overlap way too much by calculating the amount of overlap, so if a building shares space for 90% with another building, it's not a relation, it's a problem.  If they do share the same references, it's easy to decide, I just drop the oldest one, assuming it's just 2 versions that are in the export.  But once in a while the old geometry seems to be better than the more recent one.  There is not golden rule to decide this.  just some common sense which to an extent I can program by calculations.   There's a big cut-off usually.  like 0.3% shared space is visually already a lot, but when we go to like +5%, that's a problem.  Not sure about the threshold by heart, it's in the code but I do remember it wasn't really a big deal deciding on that.
Thu, Feb 10, 2022, 17:09:38 - @gplv2:matrix.org: so the easy ones are : contains, when 1 poly is totally inside another poly and they have different ID's and/or dates.   because that is the same as a relation with inner/outer, only on a multipolygon/relation the tags are not present on the member, so I can make the distinction there.  total overlaps are super easy to detect.  partial overlaps take a bit more logic
Thu, Feb 10, 2022, 17:10:17 - @gplv2:matrix.org: in gis the functions are ST_Overlap / ST_Intersect / ST_Contains / ST_isWithin and so on.   they are used to make the tree of decisions.
Thu, Feb 10, 2022, 17:11:39 - @gplv2:matrix.org: logic starts here : https://github.com/gplv2/grbtool/blob/81e86f5e87e1430353996331c1f3b625d8540c34/public/js/overpass.js#L365
Thu, Feb 10, 2022, 17:16:56 - @gplv2:matrix.org:                                     
```
var overlapsize = mturf.area(inter);
                                    var areasizeA = mturf.area(featureA);
                                    var areasizeB = mturf.area(featureB);
                                    var maxarea = (areasizeA > areasizeB) ? areasizeA : areasizeB;
                                    var overlappct = ( overlapsize / maxarea) * 100;
                                    var perc_overlap = Math.round(( overlappct  + Number.EPSILON) * 100) / 100;

                                    if (perc_overlap > 0.8 ) {
```
Thu, Feb 10, 2022, 17:17:02 - @gplv2:matrix.org: 0.8 %
Thu, Feb 10, 2022, 17:17:33 - @gplv2:matrix.org: of the max area, so of the biggest poly of the 2
Thu, Feb 10, 2022, 17:17:54 - @gplv2:matrix.org: anything bigger than that is a problem and when you see 0.8% it's already a lot
Thu, Feb 10, 2022, 17:19:32 - @gplv2:matrix.org: I must add, that overlap isn't per definition a 'version' problem, it can also be an accuracy issue, but all steps before that scan for those cases and at export the smaller ones that overlap will get snapped together at their edges, so you don't have to do that in josm anymore
Thu, Feb 10, 2022, 17:20:11 - @gplv2:matrix.org: but we just can't accept overlaps that are 2/3 meters deep can we ?

Thu, Feb 10, 2022, 17:57:08 - @gplv2:matrix.org: the only problem is : I can't tell from the meta data like in GRB we can as roof maps 1 on 1 with osm roof 
Thu, Feb 10, 2022, 17:59:02 - @gplv2:matrix.org: in PICC it can be either : verdieping or dak (GRB equivalent).  the difference is :  a verdieping has space where you can live, so atleast 1 extra floor, where a 'roof' is more like a carport without anything above it, that's what I understand from the data and checking ground truth.  So a roof _can_ be mapped without errors against OSM
Thu, Feb 10, 2022, 18:00:01 - @gplv2:matrix.org: it's not wrong.   You'll notice in PICC that those houses are made up of different components usually

Tue, Feb 15, 2022, 13:44:15 - @gplv2:matrix.org: whoever put this in the wiki : You can safely ignore them! Do not let it stop you from correcting things. If a building has clearly changed shape, just edit the building and remove source:geometry:ref=* and source:geometry:date=*. Do check if your information is more recent than the date in the source:geometry:date=* tag.


Tue, Feb 15, 2022, 13:44:19 - @gplv2:matrix.org: that's wrong
Tue, Feb 15, 2022, 13:45:01 - @gplv2:matrix.org: don't delete the tags, especially when the geometry has changed, you want to keep them as the next mapper will not replace it since the tags are gone. 
Tue, Feb 15, 2022, 13:47:27 - @gplv2:matrix.org: it's a warning of the plugin, to replace a geometry it needs an existing building AND a new one (so not in OSM ).   When OSm has 2 buildings that overlap, they are both "old" , and the geometry tool doesn't know which one needs to replace which one.  There is a simple workaround there.  Just delete the "good" one in your work layer, and paste is back at the source position, then use the merge function and it will work.  Usually , it's because someone else forgot to merge those buildings and did an upload as-is
Tue, Feb 15, 2022, 13:48:56 - @gplv2:matrix.org: in my style sheet, you can see text in yellow and in white :  white  label comes from OSM, yellow is what you copy/pasted from the exported layer.  In case both are white, you will get that warning and merge-geometry plugin will complain
Tue, Feb 15, 2022, 14:01:54 - stijn_claes: Would it not be better to add some extension in the tag value if you corrected the geometry according to the reality, source:geometry:ref=Gbg/4801143 - updated?
Tue, Feb 15, 2022, 14:04:21 - stijn_claes: Keeping the original tag does not look correct to me as the building does not longer correspond to the GRB-building
Tue, Feb 15, 2022, 14:05:25 - @gplv2:matrix.org: please don't do that :)
Tue, Feb 15, 2022, 14:05:48 - @gplv2:matrix.org: that tag is computer parsed, that would break everything
Tue, Feb 15, 2022, 14:06:23 - stijn_claes: Ok, what could be an alternative?
Tue, Feb 15, 2022, 14:06:29 - @gplv2:matrix.org: I updated the wiki.  Just leave it alone and update the shapes.   
Tue, Feb 15, 2022, 14:08:05 - stijn_claes: I can understand that it could create some problems for your tool, but just keeping them as they are does not look correct to me neither
Tue, Feb 15, 2022, 14:08:16 - @gplv2:matrix.org: <@stijn_claes:matrix.org "Keeping the original tag does no..."> since GRB/URBIS/PICC is not the "boss" when it comes to shapes, it doesn't represent that .   How can I explain this clearly ....
Tue, Feb 15, 2022, 14:13:36 - @gplv2:matrix.org: those tags are purely for the tool, people change geometries all the time, even really minor changes like snapping objects to eachother.  It's not 100% accurate, using that logic we would have to put those remarks on about every building, and it's impossible to explain and demand that from every mapper, it will just not work.   You can put a note on the object, notes are exactly used for that:  letting the next mapper know about some information

the point is not to say:  hey : this shape is EXACTLY the same as GRB.  That is totally not the meaning of the tags.   The point is giving a unique backreferencing to the source data for automation and uniquely identifying an object.   The date is chosen because it conveys more information for a human.  I could just have used the uidn value, which is meaningless but it also changes together with the date whenever source data gets updated, both change

you need to keep them because they represent the latest data in GRB.    So when the GRB date changes, that means something happened to this object and the filter will react accordingly.
Tue, Feb 15, 2022, 14:14:39 - @gplv2:matrix.org: I put notes all the time on problem cases.
Tue, Feb 15, 2022, 14:16:07 - stijn_claes: So, to play the devil's advocate, it's actually a case of 'tagging for the tool' (variant on tagging for the renderer)?
Tue, Feb 15, 2022, 14:16:46 - @gplv2:matrix.org: tagging : yes
Tue, Feb 15, 2022, 14:16:49 - @gplv2:matrix.org: mapping : no
Tue, Feb 15, 2022, 14:16:58 - @gplv2:matrix.org: it happens everywhere
Tue, Feb 15, 2022, 14:17:32 - @gplv2:matrix.org: when you check the openstreetmap-carto style, tons of backreferences are excluded from for example tile servers
Tue, Feb 15, 2022, 14:18:31 - @gplv2:matrix.org: people that just imported shapes never really took into account this simple factor :   time
Tue, Feb 15, 2022, 14:19:07 - @gplv2:matrix.org: check this file
Tue, Feb 15, 2022, 14:19:08 - @gplv2:matrix.org: https://github.com/gravitystorm/openstreetmap-carto/blob/master/openstreetmap-carto.lua
Tue, Feb 15, 2022, 14:19:15 - @gplv2:matrix.org: full of excludes
Tue, Feb 15, 2022, 14:19:33 - @gplv2:matrix.org: to name a few:
Tue, Feb 15, 2022, 14:19:40 - @gplv2:matrix.org: ```
-- NHN (CA)
    'accuracy:meters',
    'waterway:type',
    -- StatsCan (CA)
    'statscan:rbuid',

    -- RUIAN (CZ)
    'ref:ruian:addr',
    'ref:ruian',
    'building:ruian:type',
    -- DIBAVOD (CZ)
    'dibavod:id',
    -- UIR-ADR (CZ)
    'uir_adr:ADRESA_KOD',

    -- GST (DK)
    'gst:feat_id',
    -- osak (DK)
    'osak:identifier',
```

Tue, Feb 15, 2022, 14:39:30 - @gplv2:matrix.org: since they only have a version
Tue, Feb 15, 2022, 14:41:05 - @gplv2:matrix.org: not a last modified data of an object.  I searched high and low,  at one point I thought I found a date and it so happened to be a free form text field, where you notice that the data comes from all different merge/database imports/ automated and manual import work.  So you can't depend on them.  a lot have a date in there, but some have this:  "import from xyz" (as a date ... )
Tue, Feb 15, 2022, 14:42:37 - @gplv2:matrix.org: GRB is nicer though,  they have entities, Gba,Gbg,Knw... I think that is really smart btw.   That's where entity comes from, because Picc and Urbis do not use that principle, the entity is Picc/Urbis.   
Tue, Feb 15, 2022, 14:43:04 - @gplv2:matrix.org: that's why you won't see "source:geometry:ref"='Grb/1234123' but Gba/Gbg

But I could make a map between our unique id's and the OSLO standard uri's , that doesn't even exist in belgium such a mapping.   I could expose that through an API, but don't know if there is a real demand for this

Tue, Feb 15, 2022, 15:53:17 - s8evq: "the point is not to say:  hey : this shape is EXACTLY the same as GRB.  That is totally not the meaning of the tags.   The point is giving a unique backreferencing to the source data for automation and uniquely identifying an object."
I didn't know it's supposed to be seen like that.
Tue, Feb 15, 2022, 15:54:03 - s8evq: I thought that when you have the grb tags, it means "hey. this shape is EXACTLY the same as GRB.". So when I change an object, I removed the tags

Tue, Feb 15, 2022, 15:55:13 - @gplv2:matrix.org: it's strange that this is confusing because it happens all the time, seldom geometries are just copy/pasted and left untouched. Tue, Feb 15, 2022, 15:55:42 - @gplv2:matrix.org: just snapping corners together is a deviation from the source data,  removing overnodes is too.  
Tue, Feb 15, 2022, 15:56:10 - @gplv2:matrix.org: In fact, the tool already removes the obvious overnoding automatically
Tue, Feb 15, 2022, 15:56:35 - @gplv2:matrix.org: <@s8evq:matrix.org "I thought that when you have the..."> dont change them
Tue, Feb 15, 2022, 15:57:52 - @gplv2:matrix.org: you'll end up in an endless loop of map->improve-> remove tags -> next mapper comes in -> building doesn't get filtered out -> overwrites the previous version -> you notice it's back to where you started
Tue, Feb 15, 2022, 15:58:15 - @gplv2:matrix.org: the tags are really not meant to be manhandled.  
Tue, Feb 15, 2022, 15:59:33 - @gplv2:matrix.org: because when the implication of doing so is unclear, why do it in the first place ?   It's a version control vs. the source data, not vs. reality.
Tue, Feb 15, 2022, 16:03:30 - @gplv2:matrix.org: removing results in exactly the opposite of what you're trying to achieve.    Also, suppose a shape is really wrong in GRB and you want to keep the OSM version as is, you just copy the tags on it and it will from that moment be left alone and not return in the exported data anymore.   
Tue, Feb 15, 2022, 16:12:05 - @gplv2:matrix.org: if you _really_ want to convey the fact that the source of the data does not come from GRB/PICC/URBIS , add `source:geometry=survey` for example.  It's not built in , but it would be a really simple change to the tool to filter out an object when this tag is present in the OSM data  .  see https://wiki.openstreetmap.org/wiki/Key:source:geometry
Tue, Feb 15, 2022, 16:13:07 - @gplv2:matrix.org: it would actually not be such a bad idea to 'overide' default matching in the presence of this key ( nomatter what the value is )

Tue, Feb 15, 2022, 17:28:57 - joost_schouppe: Turns out I wasn't following. 
Tue, Feb 15, 2022, 19:30:21 - s8evq: I like the idea of adding source:geometry=survey, because if the geometry has been changed manually, and you leave source:geometry=grb... then that's a lie. The source of the geometry is not GRB.
Tue, Feb 15, 2022, 19:31:45 - s8evq: <@gplv2:matrix.org "you'll end up in an endless loop..."> I thought it would be: map -> Improve -> remove tags -> next mapper comes in -> building doesn't get filtered out -> carefully verifies the to be imported building -> sees geometry is incorrect -> doesn't import
Tue, Feb 15, 2022, 19:33:02 - s8evq: Or another way: " Improve -> remove tags -> next mapper comes in -> GRB is updated in the mean time -> tags are added to the existing way (perhaps with minor geometry update)"
Tue, Feb 15, 2022, 21:15:03 - @gplv2:matrix.org: <@s8evq:matrix.org "I like the idea of adding source..."> again, the geometries are not identical in almost none of the cases in fact.   If you would know how much treatement I do on the data in each step, overnoding, snapping to eachother, glueing, removing duplicate edges,  it's a lot in each step.   The idea was never to be identical, also.  It's a lie anyway because the accuracy is to be desired for.   in Mechelen perhaps the persons measuring things does his work to perfection, the guy in Roeselare does not.  Then the GIS person enters it in GRB, but he sees an overlap and now he needs to decide which one needs to move, and so on.   The accuracy can be off till 10cm.  The point is NOT to mimic and make a hardcopy of the GRB data, it's there to guide you, it's there to make informed decisions.   The point of the tags was also chosen to adhere to the existing OSM schema and the source:geometry:* namespace was the best choice.   If I would have called it `be.ref.id` , would you be so disturbed by it ?   I think not.  So you're really just having a semantics battle here.   Not a data issue or a problem .   You're giving those tags a different meaning than what they are supposed to mean.   They have been chosen with all sorts of constraints in mind for a specific goal.   This is not the moment to question those.   They are there to backreference the source data.  full stop there.   We could have put much more in there on each building but also a constraint and a balancing exercise is to not start to pollute the database with redundant and meaningless tags too.   
Tue, Feb 15, 2022, 21:16:38 - @gplv2:matrix.org: <@s8evq:matrix.org "I thought it would be: map -> Im..."> this truly doesn't make sense with the flow of the tool in mind.    That just assumes EVERY mapper knows about that problem.  And that is never the case.  How will lets say 5 people in this channel here know about an issue with building A ?  
Tue, Feb 15, 2022, 21:19:09 - @gplv2:matrix.org: You would achieve what you want by just NOT removing the tags, thus preventing it from being exported.   Then you put a note on that object.  And when a mapper who DOES know a certain shape is bad, he will see the note and now you've communicated what you know to another person that knows.    The default for the mappers that do not know about the real situation is then to not touch (and prevent them from touching)  the building at all.   The default here is perfect.   If you require so many actions to achieve a goal, you're going to be the only one doing it that way .... 
Tue, Feb 15, 2022, 21:24:42 - @gplv2:matrix.org: <@s8evq:matrix.org "Or another way: " Improve -> rem..."> I think you don't understand the process when I read this.   When GRB data is updated, the date of the object changes (last update).   So even if the reference is in OSM, the tool also compares the date, then it sees the date is larger, it will not filter the building out.   At that point when you merge in JOSM, you get a merge conflict.  again pinpointing to the mapper in JOSM yelling:  HEY THIS BUILDING HAS CHANGED, you need to decide on what to do here.  in 99% of the cases, that just means taking the younges date and accepting the new geometry.   In the case that geometry is bad , which will not happen a lot, you can discard the update, so you don't update the building, you leave the date untouched but you put a note in there, so you share your local knowledge to everyone in the world like that.   Tags are never 'added' to existing ways.   that makes no sense. 
Tue, Feb 15, 2022, 21:26:07 - @gplv2:matrix.org: and hypothetical , suppose we migrated everything in OSM.   What is left now (untagged) buildings , excluding exceptions is a list of buildings without source references.  Those would in theory be buildings that do not exist/ do not exist anymore (more probable) / illegally constructed 
Tue, Feb 15, 2022, 21:29:45 - @gplv2:matrix.org: the goals is to get as much of those references and shapes and make wise decisions, but to question the semantics of the tags at this point is moot tbh.   it's a feature to have the date, not a problem.   a number was also possible, but what does that say ?   It's just a lot more practical to have a date in there instead of an incrementing number.  But it would have been perfectly possible.   Realize that we would not have had this argument here.   It's just because it's a date you keep saying we're lying.  we're not.   it's a consensus made with all constraints in mind.  I explained that already.

Wed, Feb 16, 2022, 08:33:14 - s8evq: And what about old demolished building, where no new building is seen in GRB and on satellite images. Following your logic, you would like to keep those building in OSM (with demolished prefix) AND the source:grb tags, with the aim that the tool filters it out?
Wed, Feb 16, 2022, 12:32:14 - @gplv2:matrix.org: <@s8evq:matrix.org "And what about old demolished bu..."> no, if a building is gone , just delete it.  Think that is normal.   Don't think that was the logic I was trying to explain. The tool will not filter something out that isn't in the source data anymore, the filter does this :  gets GRB/PICC/URBIS source data -> downloads the buildings using overpass  -> makes the difference between what is there but one way , filter source data out with osm data.  In my experience after some time merging (where old merges happened) you get a feel for when a building is gone.

The empty area's you did here can be done in 5 minutes with it. In cases you're interested, we hang out at https://app.element.io/?#/room/#osmbe-grb:matrix.org

Als, check out https://buildings.osm.be for the tool, before using it, drop by in our channel so we can assist.
