Tue, Mar 8, 2022, 15:24:02 - @gplv2:matrix.org: <@s8evq:matrix.org "15;21 is what is how it shows in..."> think I explained the difference.  GRB uses Belgian habbits and assumes interpolation even/uneven.   OSM is international oriented, different countries have different habits and assumptions .   No rocket science.  the ; is also the official record separator in OSM.  - indicates a range.  15-16 = 15;16 but 14-16 != 14;16 , it's 14,15,16.  
Tue, Mar 8, 2022, 15:26:41 - @gplv2:matrix.org: Stekene was my test area, had a friend there with local knowledge.  And the area was pristine and virgin with almost no buildings,  when you do Stekene, you will notice the power of the difference fucntionality.   I assume since 4/5 years that the area has developped enough to get some diffs.    But it could also be an area where some mistakes are to be found since it was during development that I worked there.   My friend since then moved.
Tue, Mar 8, 2022, 15:30:45 - @gplv2:matrix.org: <@dentonny:matrix.org "In crab staan sommige adressen o..."> that is usually a bad migration into GRB.   Often you'll see that only 1 has the nr 28.   My own building suffers from the same problem, 4 numbers on the right, 7 on the left.  But officially all the left numbers are also put on the right side.  Not a lot I can do about (GRB-wise).  Crab is a tad more accurate in those cases.  But when you see an address node in the middle, you need to be cautious as that could be some lazy asignment.  Best is to doublecheck with a survey , that will tell you exactly what the error is.   After a while you start to recognize these issues. 
Tue, Mar 8, 2022, 15:36:15 - Ivan Lievens: @gplv2:matrix.org: I think you forget all the ABC... variants in 14,15,(16) for 14-16
Tue, Mar 8, 2022, 15:36:27 - @gplv2:matrix.org: define : forget 
Tue, Mar 8, 2022, 15:39:52 - Ivan Lievens: @gplv2:matrix.org: could  also be 14,14A, 14B,15,15A,16?
Tue, Mar 8, 2022, 15:40:24 - @gplv2:matrix.org: Sure
Tue, Mar 8, 2022, 15:40:26 - @gplv2:matrix.org: https://github.com/gplv2/grb2osm/blob/d1c41e3a4f81909e5e1644f4c1e10684e5185b2f/grb2osm.php#L1387
Tue, Mar 8, 2022, 15:40:37 - @gplv2:matrix.org: I did not forget, if you would read that code
Tue, Mar 8, 2022, 15:40:53 - @gplv2:matrix.org: it supports flattening and compressing those too
Tue, Mar 8, 2022, 15:41:49 - @gplv2:matrix.org: But they are not clumped together, numeric values are treated seperately from alfanumeric housnumbers
Tue, Mar 8, 2022, 15:42:16 - @gplv2:matrix.org: so if you would have 14A 14B, 14C , 14 D it will be compressed into 14A-14D
Tue, Mar 8, 2022, 15:42:59 - @gplv2:matrix.org: that code does all it can in order to get the smallest housnumber possible without having a line of 250 characters
Tue, Mar 8, 2022, 15:43:17 - @gplv2:matrix.org: and still be accurate of course
Tue, Mar 8, 2022, 15:44:13 - @gplv2:matrix.org: the only little issue I think it has (think joost_schouppe also noticed that a while back) is that the sorting of that mix is not natural
Tue, Mar 8, 2022, 15:44:36 - @gplv2:matrix.org: or not natural enough..  :  see https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Natural_sort_order
Tue, Mar 8, 2022, 15:49:20 - @gplv2:matrix.org: if I remember correctly, it does like left -> all digits only  ,  concats all the alfanumeric ones behind it.   It's a little artifact that is not entirely 'human' order as humans tend to think differently.   eg, we consider this to be a better order :  14, 14A,14B, 15,15A etc.  I think that code does : 14,15,14A,14B,15A .   the former is better and more logical to humans. And I aggree it could use some tweaks.   I was planning on fixing that when a new GRB DB preparation is done.   I'm planning on doing trimestrial updates, so at the end of this month, we'll redo all data Picc/GRB/Urbis.
Tue, Mar 8, 2022, 15:52:21 - @gplv2:matrix.org: but half ot that code is throwing away thrash like  :  14.1 , 14.0001 .   CRAB/GRB really has a lot of pure shit in it imho.   And let's not get started on the bus numbers, that field does not have any national rules (of regional).   The real problem is that every commune/GIS-responable-person seems to do it his/her way.

Wed, Mar 9, 2022, 14:24:58 - juminet: Hello. I completed my first submunicipality (Longlier, Neufchateau) with importing PICC buildings. Actually, it was a mixed situation with about 3/4 of buildings and address already there and 1/4 to complete. I took me a long time to do the conflation of existing buildings to the imported ones, actually much much more longer than the situation where there are no buildings at all. I was using the CTRL+SHIFT+G (from utilsplugin2) to do so, so I had to do it building per building. Using this, the original OSM object is actually deleted, which is not great, but at least any other tags that were not present on the PICC building is kept. I've read somewhere here that adding the "source:geometry:ref" tag was useful, but is it really? I mean, if we want to compare stuffs, shapes might be compared using spatial queries. I also fear that doing so we might delete better buildings shape that were introduced by a local mapper. So to be discussed, but I have some doubt about adding the PICC tags where there are alaready buildings, and I'd prefer to focus on parts where there are no buildings at all, or buildings with very poor geometry (like a single building object for several houses).

Wed, Mar 9, 2022, 19:55:46 - s8evq: Using the CTRL-SHIFT-G shortcut, it does indeed looks visually like the old building is being deleted (first you have two shapes on top of eachother, after you press CTRL-SHIFT-G the old one is gone).  But what actually happens is that JOSM moves and changes the old shape to the position of the new shape. And the new shape (that's not even uploaded) get's deleted. So you end up with only one shape. It has the ID and history of the old shape, but in the geometry and position of the new shape.
Wed, Mar 9, 2022, 19:56:03 - s8evq: Perhaps there's the confusion about the deletion with ctrl+shift+g?
Wed, Mar 9, 2022, 19:58:50 - s8evq: For example Ivan Lievens , this is one I did recently https://www.openstreetmap.org/way/148110300/history
Wed, Mar 9, 2022, 19:59:09 - s8evq: I made it jump from version 7 to version 8.
Wed, Mar 9, 2022, 19:59:51 - s8evq: Now we still know who added what tags etc...
Wed, Mar 9, 2022, 20:21:36 - juminet: eh that's right! didn't realise that.
Thu, Mar 10, 2022, 08:37:03 - joost_schouppe: that's why I asked Ivan Lievens for a changeset ID, if you open a changeset in achavi (e.g. https://overpass-api.de/achavi/?changeset=118250547) you get a nice visualisation of what you have deleted vs replaced. Also https://osmlab.github.io/osm-deep-history/#/way/148110300 is fun to understand why it's always great to use replace geometry (ctrl shift g) instead of delete

Thu, Mar 10, 2022, 16:04:30 - Ivan Lievens: <@s8evq:matrix.org "Now we still know who added what..."> When you copy/merge all the attributes/history from the old building to the new one and delete the old you should get the same result?
Thu, Mar 10, 2022, 16:43:43 - s8evq: <@ivan.lievens:matrix.org "When you copy/merge all the attr..."> No, I don't think so. When I mention 'history', I mean by that the overview of the different version of an object. When you create a new object, it starts at version 1. When you reuse the old object, you go from (for example) version 7 to version 8.
Thu, Mar 10, 2022, 16:44:10 - s8evq: With a tool like this one: osm.mapki.com/history/way.php?id=148110300
Thu, Mar 10, 2022, 16:44:24 - s8evq: we can see when and how a tag got added, and by who, in what changeset.
Thu, Mar 10, 2022, 16:44:53 - s8evq: That's the valuable information that would be lost if you create a new object with version one.
Thu, Mar 10, 2022, 16:45:10 - s8evq: It's not that big of a deal when you delete the old one and make a new object.
Thu, Mar 10, 2022, 16:45:28 - s8evq: But when you think of it, and have a choice, it's better to try and keep the old geometry.

Thu, Mar 10, 2022, 17:35:27 - joost_schouppe: it's not a delete of the "way", hence it's not a delete of the building. Yes, the old geometry was deleted, but you can query the old versions of the current "way" to know how the geometry was before

Thu, Mar 10, 2022, 17:37:01 - joost_schouppe sent an image. (Media omitted)
Thu, Mar 10, 2022, 17:44:31 - Ivan Lievens: <@joost_schouppe:matrix.org "yes, this can happen in some rar..."> I'm not promoting to delete buildings. I do it when an old building consists of 2 ways and the new one of only one. Normally I keep (merge) the one closest to the street and delete the other one. Mostly of the type with one tag building=yes.
Thu, Mar 10, 2022, 17:48:49 - joost_schouppe: That makes total sense
Thu, Mar 10, 2022, 18:06:28 - @gplv2:matrix.org: <@juminet:matrix.org "Hello. I completed my first subm..."> Hi, it's indeed a lot of work, I sure hope you used the filter function as once the backreferences are in OSm it starts to get easier as they will filter out properly.  You need to look at it as now you're verifying what exists in OSM against the official shapes.   The reference tag is quite useful, I explained this a zillion times already, it sure is a lot better than just dumping the shapes in OSM.  It's also non-intruisive, it is done for you when the correct procedure is followed, it costs no extra effort.   Shapes aren't compaired with spatial queries with the tool but using those references, in that way a better shape can be kept and when you keep the official reference, it will be disregarded by the next mapper since it will get filtered out.   You will only notice when a geometry is "poor"when you actually try to merge data.   I've made tools to do spatial comparisons but you need to realise those cannot work without a certain treshold or the slighest movement /snap of a point will change the shape.   I do have quite some decent results with Urbis data and some advanced algo's.   The replace-geometry (utils plugin) keeps the history of a building (the way).  It might add or delete some nodes, but the way OSM id is kept and is the same.   That is the entire reason that this tool is a must-have/must-use.   I suggest remapping it to ctrl-shift-A as that is a LOT easier to repeatedly use in JOSM.   A note on the references (the entire one is the date + the ref btw, not only the ref) .  It's imperative to use that.   It conveys a lot of information and we need to think about the future as well, in case we would have imported everything and in 5 years down the road, many things will change, without it we would NOT even know where to start and people would just start importing shape files again without those references in there it's mopping the floor with the water running.   I think I can say I know a thing or 2 about database /big data handling and it might just be very obvious for me why it is very important to have those references in there and not so obvious for others.   But trust me on this, in a few years this effort is going to prove to be a very good investments and the quality of OSM in Belgium will be awesome.   If a OSM geometry is better, the solution is simple:  keep it, but migrate the references.   Eventually the measured official data will also improve and the 2 will meet at one point.   With every upgrade/update of the source data whenever it changed we can see the difference and decide which one to keep.   But everyone needs to use it ,  if everyone starts to decide if it's needed or not and deviates from the procedure, then it will become useless and that will become a selffulfilling prophecy.   Just keep it there.  all your concerns are valid, but they have been covered/thought about and tackled already.

Thu, Apr 21, 2022, 15:14:33 - gpoilvet: Wat kan je er mee doenüòÖ?
Thu, Apr 21, 2022, 15:21:02 - MikiDi: CRAB is de Vlaamse referentiedatabank adressen. V√≥or grbosm een ding was, hadden we http://crab-import.osm.be (ook ontwikkeld door Glenn) om te helpen met adressen importeren. Met grbosm worden de meeste adressen meteen mee aan de gebouwen gehangen en is crab-import deels obsolete, maar het bestaat nog steeds en geeft vanuit een ietwat ander perspectief zicht op de "dekkingsgraad" van adressen in OSM. De knop "open in CRAB import" is volgens mij niet meer dan een shortcut naar crab-import om gemakkelijk dat "andere perspectief" te raadplegen indien nodig.
Thu, Apr 21, 2022, 15:26:59 - joost_schouppe: De ruwe CRAB data is vooral handig als GRB weer eens de mist in gaat. Bijvoorbeeld huisnummers onterecht aan twee gebouwen gekoppeld; negeren dat een hoekhuis adressen heeft van meerdere straten; het huisnummer niet aan het gebouw hangen (waardoor een rijhuis opeens building=yes is en geen adres heeft)

Sat, Apr 23, 2022, 08:14:15 - joost_schouppe: Hier is gok ik het volgende gebeurd:
Sat, Apr 23, 2022, 08:15:17 - joost_schouppe: - het adres 17 werd automatisch op dit gebouw geprikt en er ook aan gekoppeld
- de crab beheerder zag dat het fout was en heeft dat manueel goed gelegd
- maar de crabbeheerder heeft de link tussen fout gebouw en adres niet gebroken
Sat, Apr 23, 2022, 08:15:45 - joost_schouppe: Dus nr 17 zou je nu boven op een ander ge ouw moeten zien liggen, maar zonder een correcte koppeling met een gebouw

Tue, May 3, 2022, 20:56:51 - joost_schouppe: Finally managed to finish Overboelare, Geraardsbergen

Mon, May 9, 2022, 16:12:30 - joost_schouppe: For reporting changes to the governement without hassle, I'd like to propose this workflow:
- when the official source has a building that does not exist anymore, we actually import it with `razed:building=*` instead of `building=*`, and keep the ref tags. That way, we can easily extract all the buildings we believe do not exist anymore. This also avoids people accidentaly adding the building later In complicated cases (huge old geometry, confusing overlaps with current geometry etc), we could create just a node (the centroid I guess) and put the tags there.
- when the official source does not know yet about a new building, we add `source:geometry:ref=missing` to the building we manually draw
In both cases of course, only if it is truly missing in the data source (i.e. missing in the background map), not if it is simply missing in buildings.osm.be (which can and does happen of course)
Mon, May 9, 2022, 16:13:41 - joost_schouppe: This misses cases with a significant change in geometry though. In these cases maybe we could simply use `source:geometry:date=outdated`
Tue, May 10, 2022, 15:41:17 - s8evq: That sounds like a good idea üëçÔ∏è
Tue, May 10, 2022, 16:03:02 - juminet: Great! I'll mention these rules in the meetup on monday.
Tue, May 10, 2022, 17:29:40 - joost_schouppe: Let's document it in the wiki somewhere then
Thu, May 12, 2022, 09:30:40 - joost_schouppe: Juminet, for the meetup, maybe we should ask participants to try and install JOSM already in advance
Thu, May 12, 2022, 09:42:07 - joost_schouppe: @room : I've added a section to the wiki: https://wiki.openstreetmap.org/wiki/WikiProject_Belgium/Building_and_address_import/Instructions#Dealing_with_errors_in_the_source_data - please use that logic, and let mle know if you've covered a significant area using this method!

Wed, May 18, 2022, 22:16:16 - eMerzh: how do you deal with faulty PICC street names ? like Witthem != Withem ... OSM is correct ofc ... 
Wed, May 18, 2022, 22:19:42 - joost_schouppe: In Flanders, the name in the database is always "correct" as in "the official truth". So it's always worth keeping the official spelling somewhere (usually official_name). The name on the street sign is then officially wrong, and should be changed some day.
Form what I understand of ICAR data quality, things are different in Wallonia? Though I'm not familiar enough to be sure
Thu, May 19, 2022, 09:30:47 - joost_schouppe: @room : I've updated the Instructions document with a little more info on how to deal with errors in the address data. https://wiki.openstreetmap.org/wiki/WikiProject_Belgium/Building_and_address_import/Instructions#Resolving_common_address_issues . Please discuss address issues in Wallonia here before reporting (until we have a better understanding of the types of issues we encounter!)

Thu, Aug 11, 2022, 12:07:03 - joost_schouppe: Jakka_Frank: building:part always needs to be within an actual building (or is sometimes mapped with building=* as well). In Wallonia, all the anexes of buildings are separate, but from what we heard from the PICC people, it has little meaning. So it's probably easiest to just merge buildings like this into a single building https://www.openstreetmap.org/way/1060511361/history

Thu, Aug 11, 2022, 15:18:52 - joost_schouppe: dus scenario 1: Walloni√´
- selecteer de betrokken gebouwdelen
- toets shift+j
- JOSM vraagt om conflicten op te lossen tussen tags. Kies voor de ref-tags bij "Waarde" voor "alles"
Thu, Aug 11, 2022, 15:21:23 - joost_schouppe: scenario 2: Vlaanderen:
* kijk welke gebouwdelen samenhoren
* verwijder van al die gebouwen de building-tag, de fixme en de adresgegevens (kopieer het adres en het juiste gebouwtype even naar het geheugen)
* gebruik shrinkwrap om een nieuwe omsluitende lijn te maken (en plak daar √©nkel de adresgegevens op)
* de oorspronkelijke gebouwdelen hebben nog altijd de ref-tags. Voeg enkel nog aan alle delen building:part=yes toe, en aan zwevende delen op zijn minst building:min_level
Fri, Aug 12, 2022, 09:43:21 - dentonny: dus de building:levels tag komt dan enkel op de building:part delen te staan en niet op het geheel waar het adres op staat?
Sat, Aug 13, 2022, 15:42:21 - joost_schouppe: Correct

Sun, Sep 4, 2022, 14:33:24 - nielsdg: ```
[out:json][timeout:25];
(
  way["building"]["source:geometry:date"!~".*"]({{bbox}});
);
out meta center;
```

Tue, Sep 6, 2022, 15:28:36 - @juliusone:matrix.org joined the room
Tue, Sep 6, 2022, 16:02:12 - @juliusone:matrix.org: Hi!
I am currently importing my first buildings using the tool.  In the area I selected, some houses are split in multiple parts in the PICC data.  However, the parts do not make sense on their own and I would like to merge the parts together.  What value should I keep for source:geometry:ref and source:geometry:date?
Tue, Sep 6, 2022, 16:02:28 - @juliusone:matrix.org sent an image. (Media omitted)
Tue, Sep 6, 2022, 16:02:37 - @juliusone:matrix.org: This is the kind of buildings I am talking about.  I would like to merge the three parts but with the SHIFT+J I have to choose a value for the tags source:geometry:*.
What are the guidelines for those situations?
Thanks!
Tue, Sep 6, 2022, 16:17:06 - timcouwelier: you can opt to keep them all
Tue, Sep 6, 2022, 16:17:21 - timcouwelier: in which case it merges and lists the unique ID's in a numeration
Tue, Sep 6, 2022, 16:17:37 - timcouwelier: like GBG34309;GBG32094;... 
Tue, Sep 6, 2022, 16:18:02 - timcouwelier: (I'm not sure how they look like for PICC-sourced data though)
Tue, Sep 6, 2022, 16:18:12 - timcouwelier: but you should be able to check a 'keep all' box
Tue, Sep 6, 2022, 16:19:48 - @juliusone:matrix.org: Thanks!  What about the source:geometry:date tag?  Do I keep them all as well or only the most recent?
Tue, Sep 6, 2022, 16:23:21 - timcouwelier: it'll enumerate all the unique dates for the blocks
Tue, Sep 6, 2022, 16:23:28 - timcouwelier: so if all the same, you'll only get the one
Tue, Sep 6, 2022, 16:23:55 - timcouwelier: if there's multiple, it'll store all in a similar way
Tue, Sep 6, 2022, 16:25:21 - joost_schouppe: I do the same; also for the date I keep all the dates
Tue, Sep 6, 2022, 17:02:30 - @juliusone:matrix.org: Thanks for the hints.  Here is my first changeset with the tool.  Any feedback?
https://www.openstreetmap.org/changeset/125863192
Tue, Sep 6, 2022, 17:28:47 - juminet: Nice! 
Tue, Sep 6, 2022, 17:30:06 - juminet: IMHO I wouldn't merge the buildings. It takes time and split buildings can be useful for setting different attributes on the building such as roof shape, height, colors, ... These tags are used for 3D rendering for instance.
Tue, Sep 6, 2022, 17:31:44 - juminet: In my experience with importing the PICC, the quality is not always there. There is a problem of "overnoding": too much nodes along straight lines. it can be boring deleting them. But this is definitely faster than drawing by hand...
Tue, Sep 6, 2022, 17:33:13 - juminet: After a while working on a area, I check on osmose.openstreetmap.fr if there are some errors of overlapping buildings and space between buildings. These errors are not always spotted by JOSM. 
Tue, Sep 6, 2022, 17:50:21 - nielsdg: <@juminet:matrix.org "IMHO I wouldn't merge the buildi..."> you could still merge them (or a copy of them) and the mark the specific parts as "building:part=yes" (or even "building:part=roof")
Tue, Sep 6, 2022, 17:50:57 - nielsdg: for the GRB import, you usually have to do something like that for building parts that need something like "building:min_level=1"
Tue, Sep 6, 2022, 17:51:50 - nielsdg: The tag is described here https://wiki.openstreetmap.org/wiki/Key:building:part (although the wiki seems to be down for me)
Tue, Sep 6, 2022, 18:04:31 - @juliusone:matrix.org: For the buildings, I think it makes sense to merge the parts when it's a house for example: having multiple buildings to represent a single house on the map is kind of wired.  
I get the need to specify the different parts, especially if they are present in the PICC source data for 3D rendering.  The building:part=* tag seems well suited for that and I'll use this 
Tue, Sep 6, 2022, 18:04:50 - midgard: overnoding can be solved with a plugin "SimplifyArea" (also works for non-areas), shortcut Ctrl+Shift+Y
Tue, Sep 6, 2022, 18:06:53 - @juliusone:matrix.org: For the overnoding, I'll install SimplifyArea and have a try!  Should I make the buildings orthogonal when they nearly are in PICC? Angles are sometimes close to 90 degrees but are not perfectly 90 degrees
Tue, Sep 6, 2022, 18:42:10 - joost_schouppe: from what I understood from the PICC people, the devision into building parts is not usually meaningful on their end. juminet do you have another impression?
Tue, Sep 6, 2022, 21:37:12 - juminet: About building division, it depends on the place, but in many cases I found it meaningful, like old Arden farms divided between house and stable, even if under the same roof. But sometimes, yes, it is non-sense (artefact with small thin building glued to another)

It's annoying using the default relation editor. Instead click on a member, then richt click on the relation it is part of and choose something like "select relation". Then you can select multiple tags at once

Mon, Sep 26, 2022, 22:24:43 - stijn_claes: Am I the only one who becomes a bit concerned about the fact that the database of buildings which we are importing has not been updated for a long while? Ok, we do a controlled import and a lot of buildings remain the same for a long long time, but it just seems a pity of the effort...
Mon, Sep 26, 2022, 22:58:59 - @juliusone:matrix.org: It's true that most of the buildings I am importing in Wallonia from PICC are from 2016 or 2017 for the most recent ones. However, I still see it as a valuable addition to OSM data : I focus on villages and towns where building and address coverage is poor or non existent and OSM has better coverage in those regions after the data is imported. Even if the data is somewhat old and not frequently updated it is a better quality than drawing from aerial imagery. Plus, the import tool adds very little overhead to the task and futurproofs the import in case the data source is ever updated.
In any case, OSM benefits from this data. At worst it's a one shot import and in the best case it's possible to update OSM easily.
That's how I see it üòâ 
Mon, Sep 26, 2022, 23:03:57 - stijn_claes: Of course there is a benefit for OSM, but -in the case of GRB in Flanders- I think it's a bit a pity that we are putting effort in the import while actually there is already a more recent dataset available. I certainly don't want to blame Glenn, but I would certainly be a good thing if more people could sync the databases which we are importing with the latest GRB, PICC and Urbis data
Tue, Sep 27, 2022, 09:36:17 - s8evq: That's true, I agree.

Mon, Nov 7, 2022, 09:26:25 - joost_schouppe: <@pulpfiction1234:matrix.org "98 and 100 have also housenumber..."> that's why buildings.osm.be doesnt't show the housenumber. The tool only includes addresses if all the addresses are from the same street. Otherwise it's impossible to add them to the building itself. It's always good to have urbis-admin as a background, so you'll see those addresses
Mon, Nov 7, 2022, 09:29:15 - joost_schouppe: It's a very small changeset, so there's not much that could go wrong :)
The only suggestion I would have is to use the replace geometry function instead of deleting the old building. You can just pick any of the new buildings when an old osm building was too big.
Mon, Nov 7, 2022, 09:30:32 - joost_schouppe: Do drop something here again if you try something a little bigger. It's always going to be tough in Brussels I think (everything connected to everything else etc)

Mon, Nov 7, 2022, 14:48:55 - s8evq: @gplv2:matrix.org: zijn tool is ook altijd wel met de disclaimer geweest dat alles nog eens nagezien moet worden, dat de tags enkel een voorstel zijn. 
Mon, Nov 7, 2022, 15:05:44 - joost_schouppe: <@stijn_claes:matrix.org "What is the difference between H..."> H: has a tag related to an import, I: has the current import related tags (i.e. in Brussels H are all buildings imported, regardless of tagging style. Column I has only the ones according to the current tagging -- so just the buildings that have been touched with the current import tool). So column I is useful to know how much uypdating we've done
Mon, Nov 7, 2022, 16:35:17 - joost_schouppe: <@s8evq:matrix.org "If this is the applied logic, do..."> the logic is sound (and uses landuse as well). The logic of the mapper is not sound though. if they don't want to look at building types, they should probably not be importing at all

Sun, Dec 25, 2022, 22:53:57 - pietervdvn invited robki (Robin)
Sun, Dec 25, 2022, 22:56:17 - pietervdvn: Hallo robki (Robin) 

This is the room where we talk about the Building Import Tools.

The flow to import buildings with JOSM is described in the room topic (https://hackmd.io/s/HkqtMWE8E#). MapComplete is a complimentary tool to this flow; but it is important to know this flow as well. It's also customary to make a first changeset with all details fixed and to have it reviewed here afterwards
Sun, Dec 25, 2022, 23:19:28 - robki (Robin) joined the room

Fri, Jan 6, 2023, 14:18:34 - Steven Clays: Cool. Sticking to my method for the moment...
Fri, Jan 6, 2023, 14:18:47 - Steven Clays: 1. Select building parts
Fri, Jan 6, 2023, 14:18:47 - joost_schouppe: Ttz, beter resultaat met evenveel moeite
Fri, Jan 6, 2023, 14:18:54 - Steven Clays: 2. Copy building parts
Fri, Jan 6, 2023, 14:19:02 - Steven Clays: 3. Shift J in result layer
Fri, Jan 6, 2023, 14:19:10 - Steven Clays: 4. Copy building parts again
Fri, Jan 6, 2023, 14:19:42 - Steven Clays: 5. Remove adress tags + adding building:layer; building:min_level
Fri, Jan 6, 2023, 14:19:51 - Steven Clays: Works fine for me...
Fri, Jan 6, 2023, 14:20:28 - joost_schouppe: Selecteer
Kopieer adresinformatie
Delete alles behalve grb tags
Shortcut shrinkwrap 
Voeg building tag toe aan nieuw gebouw

Sun, Jan 15, 2023, 18:41:39 - joost_schouppe: I think the idea is this: the full on GRB contains road axis and road area. If your shapefile contains those without you needing them, it's just a waste of space.

Sun, Jan 15, 2023, 18:51:49 - stijn_claes: Indeed. You can download gbg as as separate shapefile only containing the gbg's, the same for gba and knw. But you can also download GRBGis: you then download all different layers (gbg, gba, knw, adp, wvb, wrl, wgo and so on) in separate shapefiles

Sun, Jan 15, 2023, 18:53:04 - @gplv2:matrix.org: 04000 is the region/province.   B500 is the 500Meter buffer
Sun, Jan 15, 2023, 18:55:56 - stijn_claes: If you unzip the folder, you get the metadata + a folder "shapefile" which contains all different shapefiles of which GRB is composed: gbg, gba, knw, wvb, adp... This corresponds to GRBGis

Wed, Jan 25, 2023, 15:15:43 - @gplv2:matrix.org: I don't understand what you mean by all that 
Wed, Jan 25, 2023, 15:16:04 - @gplv2:matrix.org: are you just talking about the source files ?
Wed, Jan 25, 2023, 15:50:28 - stijn_claes: Ik zal het in het Nederlands zeggen: als ik het goed begrepen heb, is er de wens dat we jou kunnen ontlasten bij het bijwerken van de data die in de Building Import Tool gebruikt wordt. Dus ik dacht dat joost_schouppe , MikiDi en eventueel anderen met jou zouden bekijken hoe we dit kunnen organiseren. Is dit beperkt tot enkel het verzamelen van de meest recente GRB, UrbIS of PICC data en deze aan jou aanleveren om de data in je tool bij te werken (waarbij er nog steeds een zeker afhankelijkheid is van jouw beschikbaarheid), of is de intentie om hier verder in te gaan, bijv. ook andere mensen zijn onderlegd in de procedure om de verzamelde data op jouw server te zetten en een proces te laten doorlopen zodat deze data beschikbaar komt via de tool? Of zelfs een scenario waarbij de tool niet meer gebruik maakt van data op jouw server maar er hiervoor zelfs een nieuwe locatie wordt opgezet waar de brondata opgeladen kan worden en vervolgens verwerkt kan worden?
Wed, Jan 25, 2023, 22:15:39 - @gplv2:matrix.org: De aanvragen, download en stockage op 1 plek is wat mij het meeste tijd kost en wat ik minste graag doe,  Urbis doe ik meestal zelf wel (ik werk er) .   De verwerking van de data is een pak complexer dan de perceptie denk ik .  Ik vind het niet erg om de verwerking op te starten.   De code is al jaren publiek beschikbaar.  De procedure is wss iets minder duidelijk en gedocumenteerd.   De stockage van de source files is natuurlijk niet genoeg...   De verwerking gebeurt niet op mijn server maar op een virtuele machine die opgebouwd wordt via terraform op google cloud met alle nodige software die voorbereid en geconfigureerd wordt.  Op een bepaald punt zal die de source files dus downloaden en zijn ding doen.  Op het einde van dit process dat momenteel zo een uur of 6/7 duurt op een stevige VM (n1-highmem-8 https://gcpinstances.doit-intl.com/)  zijn er 2 databases in postgresql opgebouwd die gexporteerd worden naar file.   Op dat moment is het manueel downloaden en deze worden dan in de bestaande database server (API) getrokken.  Op dat moment is de data beschikbaar via API voor alle consumers.   Code staat allemaal op github in verschillende repo's.   Het ecosysteem zelf is verdeeld over verschillende machines.  De site draait niet op zelfde machine als de API.   Dit geld ook voor Aptum (crab tool) , maar dat proces is iets simpeler .   Maar dit staat wel op een HA systeem met 2 data servers met gesyncte data.  Die GRB dingen zijn allemaal echt zwaar verweven met elkaar.   Het is niet alleen de data maar ook veel confuguraties in haproxy(ssl , ha) , nginx -> static file serving , php-fpm voor de code.  De website API , de authenticatie en de site serving zelf zelf is geschreven in laravel 5.2 (app+api ), al tijdje EOL wel.   Op zich geen issue , ik volg exploits wel op.   Het bulk van het werk op de site wordt door javascript opgelost.   Niet echt simpel allemaal uit te leggen in detail.  Gemakkelijker zou zijn om iemand die thuis is in deze wereld de uitleg te geven en een ware backup/hulp te worden.  Die zal dan ook access krijgen via SSH naar mijn machines natuurlijk, en eventueel in staat zijn om dit te onderhouden, bij te werken.

Mon, Feb 13, 2023, 10:21:38 - stijn_claes: Aha, die vraag kwam dus van mij... ik heb ondertussen ook al een antwoordje op jouw bericht gestuurd:
_Ik denk dat die kaart vooral het levenslicht heeft gezien wanneer er vragen kwamen, bijv. vanuit stad Tongeren, om systematisch een volledige (deel)gemeente aan te pakken. Daarnaast zijn er ook een aantal gebruikers die op een systematische manier hele gemeenten (en dus niet enkel zones) willen importeren en dat is waar dit ook opgevolgd wordt in deze uMap._

_Als je Voeren, Landen of andere (deel)gemeenten volledig hebt gecontroleerd en ge√Ømporteerd, is het misschien wel nuttig om jouw werk hieraan toe te voegen (helaas niet de meest gebruiksvriendelijke omgeving)._

_Er zijn inderdaad ook omgevingen waarin je op gebouwniveau kan zien of een gebouw al dan niet ge√Ømporteerd werd: - https://play.osm.be/historischekaart.html#17/51.16308/4.75393/BasiskaartGRBVL-OSMbuildings ‚Äì> werkt vlot, maar volgt Mapbox (dus hier kan een paar weken vertraging op zitten) - https://umap.openstreetmap.fr/nl/map/grb-import-organic_804007#18/51.16009/4.74880 ‚Äì> is steeds recent, maar werkt nogal traag_

I kind of ignored the issue after that and only kept the official language on the building addresses

Sat, Apr 8, 2023, 23:19:38 - rubosm: Ik denk dat je hier inderdaad best `addr:flats=22-24` kan zetten op het gebouw waarvan ik hieronder in Lara/CRAB de details bevraagd heb.
Ik lees ook `Where the building only has one entrance or there are multiple entrances but each entrance is not marked for a specific set of flats, then you can either tag addr:flats=* on the main entrance=* node, or or the building=* way.` op https://wiki.openstreetmap.org/wiki/Key:addr:flats ('How to map').
Sat, Apr 8, 2023, 23:19:41 - rubosm sent an image. (Media omitted)
Sat, Apr 8, 2023, 23:20:27 - rubosm: √©n `addr:housenumber=52` moet er ook op elk gebouw bij.
Sat, Apr 8, 2023, 23:27:01 - rubosm: Zelf jarenlang op CRAB-, Adressen-, Wegen- en Gebouwenregisterprojecten gewerkt. In het Gebouwenregister is het de bedoeling dat je in deze situatie √©√©n gebouw hebt met drie gebouweenheden, waarbij elk van de gebouweenheden een apart adres (huisnummer + busnummer) krijgt (daarnaast wordt vanaf minstens 2 gebouweenheden een 'gemeenschappelijk deel' voorzien dat het huisnummer draagt). Het onderscheid bus-/appartementsnummer dat vroeger in het CRAB gemaakt werd, valt in het Adressenregister weg. Daar wordt altijd over een busnummer gesproken wanneer je iets aan een adres wil toevoegen om het uniek te maken. Op het niveau van de gebouweenheid kan echter wel een 'deurnummer' voorzien worden (het vroegere appartementsnummer, vergelijkbaar met `addr:door` in OSM).

Sun, Apr 23, 2023, 17:05:14 - juminet: Hello @flha . I was not involved from the beginning in the building import, so I don't know either. But we have another use case of "source:geometry". While doing the import, if you encounter a reference (eg PICC) shape that is obviously wrong compared to the most recent imagery or your local knowledge, it is asked to add "source:geometry=outdated". So it might conflict with the tag you propose. 
Sun, Apr 23, 2023, 17:06:01 - juminet: Sinon, content de voir des contributeurs-rices en Wallonie! N'h√©sitez pas √† dessiner votre zone d'intervention sur http://umap.openstreetmap.fr/fr/map/building-import-status_714473#9/50.6766/4.8010
Sun, Apr 23, 2023, 20:56:03 - joost_schouppe: I think the reasoning was: Osm data should be as sparse as possible. If a tag can be on the changeset, we left it there. Only if it is needed on individual objects, we add a tag there.  In an initial version we had way more tags, but there were some complaints about that. So we reduced to the bare minimum

Mon, May 15, 2023, 13:39:57 - @gplv2:matrix.org: so anything that is put 'in between existing data'  bumps up all id's
Mon, May 15, 2023, 13:40:21 - @gplv2:matrix.org: so for PICC, nothing will work if building 'nr 2 gets to be nr 3)
Mon, May 15, 2023, 13:40:42 - @gplv2:matrix.org: GRB and Urbis do work with a unique integer ID
Mon, May 15, 2023, 13:41:21 - @gplv2:matrix.org: since they are stored relational .... it sure makes sense to not use such a huge unique ID 
Mon, May 15, 2023, 13:53:09 - joost_schouppe: how many times the existinng number of buildings could you identify with a string like that?
Mon, May 15, 2023, 15:48:33 - @gplv2:matrix.org: not sure I understand this question
Mon, May 15, 2023, 15:55:47 - joost_schouppe: the unique ID has 32 digits, with each 36 options. So you could uniquely identify 6.3340287e+49 buildings with such a string
Mon, May 15, 2023, 15:59:52 - joost_schouppe: So unless I'm mistaken, there are enough digits to uniquely identify all buildings on earth, and also all buildings in the universe if every star had a planet, and then enough to do the same in more universes than are fathomable. I must be mistaken
Mon, May 15, 2023, 16:00:13 - joost_schouppe: seems like some overkill is involved
Mon, May 15, 2023, 16:00:57 - stijn_claes: Isn't this some kind of usual ESRI ID generator stuff?
Mon, May 15, 2023, 16:03:03 - joost_schouppe: I guess the ID is useful like this if you want an ID number that can (almost) never link to an object from another layer
Mon, May 15, 2023, 16:04:00 - stijn_claes: https://www.arcgis.com/home/item.html?id=6997e32c54bd40ca8ca13e1fdaf5948b#! --> some kind of universally unique identifier?
Mon, May 15, 2023, 20:14:33 - jarnoo: It's certainly an UUID, v4 to be exact. The dashes in `728424B7-4442-4F19-879B-4DB3F0BE851C` basically give it away. UUIDv4 I take from the starting `4` in the third character group
Tue, May 16, 2023, 12:08:47 - @gplv2:matrix.org: I'm pretty sure it's related to the INSPIRE standards.    I recall reading about it on the PICC website at the time.   https://inspire.ec.europa.eu/documents/Data_Specifications/INSPIRE_DataSpecification_GN_v3.0.pdf But it's not really important what and how it's made.    Thing is that it's unique.  But it's just way too long and not an ideal format for a few reasons.
Tue, May 16, 2023, 12:20:05 - @gplv2:matrix.org: With +5 Million buildings in OSM, adding such a long tag makes the OSM database larger in a way that feels like overkill.   I kept the unique ID small, based it on GRB, found a counterpart in Urbis and so it seems : did not do my homework well.   I still trying to understand why I assumed it was a static number per object.   Another reason why it's not ideal is that it's not an integer.   The unique combination is the ref (entity for GRB, 'Picc' string for Picc, 'Urbis' for Urbis) + the number in oidn.  That makes the numbers not clash between those 3 databases.   It also makes indexing really fast .   In the standard schema when you import OSM data using the appropriate tools (for instance making a tile server, or making a nominatim lookup database) almost every field is mapped to a string,   I use OSM schema as the base line.   I mold the source data in different steps towards this schema, apply conversions etc.   I could explain in detail, it's all in github source but it's not easy to understand and follow.
Tue, May 16, 2023, 12:44:57 - @gplv2:matrix.org: I modify source:geometry:oidn/uidn (internal use) to INTEGER, it makes addressing queries very fast.   If we can make a conversion towards a unique integer from the GEOREF uuid , I will not have to make any GUI changes in the interface either.   And possibly any tool using the backend directly doesn't have to .  (rfr. Pieter).   
Tue, May 16, 2023, 12:47:47 - @gplv2:matrix.org: 728424B744424F19879B4DB3F0BE851C -> it's a MD5/MD4 hash btw after analysis: Bit length: 128 , char length : 32.  The salt is missing.
Tue, May 16, 2023, 12:56:26 - @gplv2:matrix.org: https://geoportail.wallonie.be/files/documents/ClubPICC/2016-09-23/7_ClubUtilisateur_6_News.pdf
Tue, May 16, 2023, 12:56:33 - @gplv2:matrix.org: slide 15
Tue, May 16, 2023, 12:57:19 - @gplv2:matrix.org sent an image. (Media omitted)
Tue, May 16, 2023, 12:58:34 - @gplv2:matrix.org: kinda strange the Suffix description, it sure looks like an MD5 hash
Tue, May 16, 2023, 13:00:14 - @gplv2:matrix.org: converting to decimal is still a huge number that won't fit  in an INTEGER field
Tue, May 16, 2023, 14:46:03 - @gplv2:matrix.org: I kinda get though why they choose this, whenever an object changes designation, like a house becomes a water tower  (stupid one I know).  It keeps the GEOREF ID.   In GRB it would change entity hence also changes oidn/uidn.  Now why this seems utter important I don't really get but there is some method in the madness.

Tue, May 30, 2023, 13:41:03 - @gplv2:matrix.org: should be fairly browser agnostic though

Tue, May 30, 2023, 13:45:10 - @gplv2:matrix.org: I would suggest closing up JOSM and restarting it when this happens.  JOSM binds to a local port on the loopback address:  like this: 

2023-05-30 13:42:04.449 INFO: RemoteControl::Accepting remote connections on /127.0.0.1:8111
2023-05-30 13:42:04.449 INFO: RemoteControl::Accepting remote connections on /0:0:0:0:0:0:0:1:8111

This is what the linux version spits out.  (so ipv4 + ipv6 listeners)

The test in the site , before launching the export for real is to see if this port is accepting connections.  That's the error message you're getting.
Tue, May 30, 2023, 13:46:36 - @gplv2:matrix.org: it's possible though (highly) unlikely that you only have ipv6 listener that works.   that probably won't work with the site as it is now as all urls are ipv4

Wed, Jun 14, 2023, 13:30:43 - @gplv2:matrix.org: so we keep the original oid's
Wed, Jun 14, 2023, 13:31:12 - @gplv2:matrix.org: and whenever there is a new building we assign a new one.

Wed, Jun 14, 2023, 13:33:47 - @gplv2:matrix.org: The alternative :  making a digit from the long hex uniquely by converting parts is difficult.   
Wed, Jun 14, 2023, 13:34:34 - @gplv2:matrix.org: I tried several mathematical algorithm already... it's not adequate
Wed, Jun 14, 2023, 15:32:21 - joost_schouppe: A mapping seems plausible. But what is worrying is that the same objectid is likely to mean different things at different times. So I would assume that from now on, you would create an objectid under your control that is saved in your mapping table 
Fri, Jun 16, 2023, 09:35:50 - @gplv2:matrix.org: not sure if I understand your concerns.   The objectID is now just a number, and when we can just keep those.   Only thing that we need for the 'diff' to work is a change in the date.  So since I still have the old database dumps and the new that's online, I can create a mapping table.   Anything that is new will receive an new object number, not based on the current uid's (of the old db) of course (we take a max(oid) and then start counting upwards for those).  In case something changed on existing entities, the modif\_date should be different.    It's just a matter of replacing the new DB ID's with the mapped one from the older ones for matching GEOREF's , and for the new... generate unique ones and store them in the mapping table.
Fri, Jun 16, 2023, 10:19:35 - joost_schouppe: oh OK, yes, then the import can just go on!

Sat, Jul 1, 2023, 15:33:54 - LePirlouit: euh noh, not the same, sorry :-D
Sat, Jul 1, 2023, 15:57:49 - @gplv2:matrix.org: <@lepirlouit2:matrix.org "Geometries are not exactly the s..."> probably because he uses direct imports from the GRB sources.   The buildings in the tool are slightly manipulated.  For example to combat overnoding.   You don't need like 20 nodes to represent a straight line, you only need 2.  But the source data from surveyors is detailed, they take multiple samples and it's entered as such.   For our goals, that is excess in nodes.   So if you want to recognize a straight import from shape files, look for excess in nodes, if the data you look at has many more nodes, especially in 'rounded' walls etc.  It's 95% sure the case.

Wed, Jul 5, 2023, 11:21:22 - gpoilvet: I have a theoretical question
Wed, Jul 5, 2023, 11:23:28 - gpoilvet: If you have an already non GRB building which has building parts with building levels and you want to merge it with the GRB building which has building parts but that are totally different in  lay out
Wed, Jul 5, 2023, 11:23:35 - gpoilvet: how would you merge them?
Wed, Jul 5, 2023, 11:26:03 - joost_schouppe: I would either skip the building (likely!) or merge all the GRB building parts (joining the ref values with ;'s) and replace the geometry of the outer building in OSM with the GRB building outline. This involves manually snapping the osm building parts to that new outer geometry of course
Wed, Jul 5, 2023, 11:29:20 - gpoilvet: so it is no problem that you have overlapping building parts with different meaning?
Wed, Jul 5, 2023, 11:29:50 - gpoilvet: GRB meaning vs other
Wed, Jul 5, 2023, 11:39:33 - joost_schouppe: I would NOT import the GRB building parts
Wed, Jul 5, 2023, 11:49:02 - gpoilvet: ah

Wed, Jul 5, 2023, 12:22:42 - @gplv2:matrix.org: I think I can't answer that in general, this needs to be a case by case thing to decide.  But I'm not a fan either.   GRB often is administrative parts, while most building parts in OSM are there to enhance detail .

Tue, Jul 18, 2023, 16:00:13 - juminet: (in case you didn't know)
Tue, Jul 18, 2023, 16:01:53 - joost_schouppe: Hadn't heard of it! So you draw a new line and both polygons are snapped to that?
Tue, Jul 18, 2023, 16:03:07 - juminet: Exactly. Essential to draw new stuffs along forest, streams, ...
Tue, Jul 18, 2023, 16:03:33 - juminet: But not roads since snapping landuse to roads is BAD
Tue, Jul 18, 2023, 16:04:09 - juminet: Yet you may snap to roads to get the shape, and then unglue the line and then shift it, but I never try this.
Tue, Jul 18, 2023, 18:31:01 - @gplv2:matrix.org: <@dentonny:matrix.org "I don't know if it's possible bu..."> elaborate on what you mean by : boundary .   2nd sentence you can do yourself inside JOSM.  You cut/paste to another layer.  I actually do it like that personally although it's been a while.   The slippy map actually has value added.  Imagine if someone else is working in the same area, using the tool you will not clash with each-other as long as you take the 'diffs' before downloading.  Otherwise you'll need to fix merge conflicts, which is definitely not everyone's cup of tea.   I find that very intense to do.    
Tue, Jul 18, 2023, 18:31:41 - @gplv2:matrix.org: <@juminet:matrix.org "For landuse editing, the JOSM pl..."> omg, I needed that so long ago.  I always end up fixing the landuse troubles and crossings with new buildings.  Thanks for sharing
Tue, Jul 18, 2023, 18:33:00 - @gplv2:matrix.org: fixing the landuse is really good work.  When you fix landuse, the auto\_building algorithm works a lot better, so when you fix landuse and do it well, the rate of success in the tool goes up.
Wed, Jul 19, 2023, 09:59:36 - dentonny: <@gplv2:matrix.org "elaborate on what you mean by : ..."> with boundary I meant cities/hamlets/.. so let's say I could download the whole city of Geel. And then I cut/paste small areas to import, so then I know I got every building in Geel when the layer is empty. But I understand that this will also enable anyone to do large bulk imports, which is something we don't want to
Wed, Jul 19, 2023, 14:59:05 - @gplv2:matrix.org: The tool is actually written to do that for you....   You diff the existing OSM data vs the GRB data, and then you only export the difference.   If you download the whole city, that would mean you also export what already exists in OSM.   Cheapest way to verify if holes exist. is upload your changes, drag the map, wait just a little bit so the 'minute diffs' of your last upload are applied to the overpass API server,  (usually fast) and then you repeat the process, your new uploads should be filtered out.

Mon, Jul 31, 2023, 14:16:30 - jl.stanus sent an image. (Media omitted)
Mon, Jul 31, 2023, 14:16:32 - jl.stanus: Hello, i would like to continue to import buildings in Namur.
Around the university, contributors added entrance attached to the geometry building. It's a good practice as read in the wiki. 
While importing, the merge of both geometry old and the imported one cannot merge. The entrance blocks the process. I can unglue (G key in JOSM) then glue them again. but i modify the imported geometry. 
What's the best approach in your opinion?
https://www.openstreetmap.org/#map=19/50.46597/4.85994


Mon, Jul 31, 2023, 14:22:07 - @gplv2:matrix.org: That's the way
Mon, Jul 31, 2023, 14:22:15 - @gplv2:matrix.org: unglue the entrance nodes
Mon, Jul 31, 2023, 14:22:21 - @gplv2:matrix.org: merge the building
Mon, Jul 31, 2023, 14:22:27 - @gplv2:matrix.org: re-attach where appropriate
Mon, Jul 31, 2023, 14:22:33 - @gplv2:matrix.org: doublecheck the addresses
Mon, Jul 31, 2023, 14:22:43 - @gplv2:matrix.org: put the address on the node if more exist.
Mon, Jul 31, 2023, 14:33:25 - jl.stanus: ok, snif
Mon, Jul 31, 2023, 19:53:01 - midgard (@midgard:matrix.rumores.eu): or, less work: don't unglue but snap the points on the existing outline to the new one, then merge
Mon, Jul 31, 2023, 19:59:03 - midgard (@midgard:matrix.rumores.eu): merge.webm (Media omitted)
Mon, Jul 31, 2023, 20:58:13 - jl.stanus: do you use a plugin? or wich shortcut?
Mon, Jul 31, 2023, 21:17:00 - Jakka_Frank: ctrl+shift+g
Mon, Jul 31, 2023, 21:17:19 - midgard (@midgard:matrix.rumores.eu): Tools ‚Üí Move Node onto Way. default shortcut: `n`
Mon, Jul 31, 2023, 21:17:30 - midgard (@midgard:matrix.rumores.eu): Message deleted
Mon, Jul 31, 2023, 21:19:38 - Jakka_Frank: <@Jakka_Frank:matrix.org "ctrl+shift+g"> is dat niet vervangen van de oude geometrie met de nieuwe ? Maar mogelijk door die node niet werkt ...
Mon, Jul 31, 2023, 21:21:38 - midgard (@midgard:matrix.rumores.eu): Jakka_Frank: jl.stanus kan geometrie vervangen. diens vraag hier ging over die nodes die geometrie vervangen verhinderen. daarom dat ik deze makkelijke methode toon om dat probleem op te lossen: de node eerst aan de nieuwe geometrie toevoegen mbv `n`, zonder eerst af te splitsen met `g` zoals iemand anders eerst suggereerde
Mon, Jul 31, 2023, 21:23:53 - jl.stanus: yes, it's solved, thank you :)
Tue, Aug 1, 2023, 13:07:10 - @gplv2:matrix.org: da's wel idd een HEEL gemakkelijkere manier om het te doen.   Enige dat je wel moet doen is valideren, vaak staan er addressen op de nodes.  Als die duplicaat zijn met de building zou de validator dat moeten flaggen

Sun, Aug 6, 2023, 22:46:47 - stijn_claes: Small question: is there a way to immediately select two overlapping polygons in JOSM. If an area has been manually mapped using the GRB background and I'm doing the GRB import, I always need to zoom in at an edge to select the old polygon and the newly imported GRB building in order to merge them (CTRL + SHIFT + G). Maybe there is a quicker way?
Sun, Aug 6, 2023, 23:02:32 - dentonny: Middlemousse button and hold CTRL
Sun, Aug 6, 2023, 23:20:08 - midgard (@midgard:matrix.rumores.eu): in some cases you can also select nodes and use [_Selection‚ÜíAdjacent ways_](https://wiki.openstreetmap.org/wiki/JOSM/Plugins/utilsplugin2#Select_adjacent_ways_(Shift+E)) (Shift+E) from utilsplugin2.
this is possible if there's nothing else connected to those nodes
Sun, Aug 6, 2023, 23:22:43 - midgard (@midgard:matrix.rumores.eu): select.webm (Media omitted)
Mon, Aug 7, 2023, 17:56:28 - Seppe: <@stijn_claes:matrix.org "Small question: is there a way t..."> Click on the polygon once to select one of the polygons, click a second time but while holding shift + alt (shift to add to the selection, alt to select another polygon)
Mon, Aug 7, 2023, 17:57:35 - Seppe: (alt + click can also be handy to select one of different overlapping features, you can also use this to toggle between selecting a way that is part of a relation and the relation itself)
Mon, Aug 7, 2023, 19:11:03 - joost_schouppe: That seems more practical than my workaround. I use the lasso to select nodes at the corner, then shift+e to select the ways the nodes belong to instead
Mon, Aug 7, 2023, 21:05:29 - dentonny: wow those ways are way better than that middle mouse click
Mon, Aug 7, 2023, 21:59:37 - stijn_claes: I'm confronted with long load times in the building tool (since a few days/weeks). Am I the only one who is having that problem?
Mon, Aug 7, 2023, 22:13:30 - stijn_claes: Do you click inside the polygon or on the boundary, because selecting one polygon and then clicking 'inside the other polygon' while holding ALT + SHIFT does not work here? Main issue is that the boundaries of manually well mapped buildings are very close to each other, so I always need to zoom in now and select both boundaries while holding CTRL
Mon, Aug 7, 2023, 22:18:02 - Jakka_Frank: Me too sometime think it down....
Mon, Aug 7, 2023, 22:18:37 - Seppe: If two buildings overlap almost perfectly (as you describe), you just select the first building by clicking on one of the boundaries and then without moving the mouse, you click while holding alt + shift to select the second building.
Mon, Aug 7, 2023, 22:19:22 - stijn_claes: @gplv2:matrix.org: are you aware of any performance issues?
Mon, Aug 7, 2023, 22:20:09 - stijn_claes: Aha, that works! Thanks!
Mon, Aug 7, 2023, 22:21:24 - Seppe: Not that hard to get it into your muscle memory and from then on, it's a huge difference to zooming in and selecting the other building (which I also used to do, I think this alt + shift clicking hasn't always been possible in JOSM)
Mon, Aug 7, 2023, 22:22:13 - Jakka_Frank: yes loading grb data takes long..... When searching adress and center it its waiting long time...

Mon, Aug 7, 2023, 22:24:34 - Seppe: Yeah, but only in the beginning :-)

Sat, Aug 12, 2023, 22:23:21 - @gplv2:matrix.org: alle queries gaan super snel in feite, maar voor sommige zijn er wel heel veel
Sat, Aug 12, 2023, 22:23:44 - @gplv2:matrix.org: de data wordt in 2 fases opgehaald wanneer de map versleept wordt bv, of opengedaan.
Sat, Aug 12, 2023, 22:25:50 - @gplv2:matrix.org: eerste is alle gebouwen in de bounding box (met marge).    Voor al die gebouwen wordt dan de osm data lokaal geraadpleegd.   dingen als landuse, bestaande tags wanneer die nieuw gebouwen kruisen etc.    Dus tegen de OSM db (maar een lokale versie die ook vernieuwd wordt bij nieuwe data).   Dat stuk dient voor de prediction/algo voor de auto_building tag.   Stel dat er 300 gebouwen staan, voor je het resultaat krijgt zijn er dus 301 queries gedaan.    Maar dit alles gaat snel

Sat, Oct 21, 2023, 09:40:59 - juminet: <@emerzh:matrix.org "I come accros ""oldish""" picc i..."> Hello. Yes, it is a known issue. We used the wrong ID of the PICC for the source:geometry:ref. Since Glenn updated the PICC data beginning of this year, we have now a new layer of PICC building data with different IDs so we cannot filter out what was imported before. It is annoying, and has been discussed a lot here. What we need to do is to correct the ref on all imported buildings and start using a good ID for PICC building. Meanwhile, I continue to import building with the new PICC layer.

Thu, Nov 30, 2023, 13:18:14 - joost_schouppe: I mean you could also just download the data in QGIS and play with the styling to highlight missing buildings (red transparent on top of blue transparent works surprisingly well!)
Thu, Nov 30, 2023, 13:26:27 - juminet: Indeed you could just use QGIS: import both PICC buildings data (or have a look if a WFS or ESRI Rest service exist for PICC), add the buildings data from OSM (using overpass-turbo for exporting) and then simply make a spatial intersection (select by location). If you need help with QGIS, just ask ;-)

Tue, Jan 2, 2024, 17:54:48 - MikiDi: I'm having a bit of a dilemma while doing Wemmel (which already isn't easy, since it is a faciliteitengemeente, I use language tags, just as in Brussels, and as seen on the ground): There are many streets named after people. The street signs across the town consistently use an abbreviated first name. Most of the existing names on the way entities followed that in the past, but in GRB (mostly, not always) the full name is used. I'd prefer following the on the ground rule, but it is somewhat of a pity that "data is lost". I'm thinking about adding `official_name` (https://wiki.openstreetmap.org/wiki/Names#Abbreviation_(don't_do_it)), or adding associated street relations and then link the etymological wikidata entity. Any ideas on that?
Tue, Jan 2, 2024, 18:13:42 - joost_schouppe: I think the no abbreviation rule overrules the on the ground rule

Fri, Feb 9, 2024, 08:10:12 - Thibaultmol: Btw, What are the main things they Mapcomplete doesn't try / can't do that you need to do manually for grb import?
Fri, Feb 9, 2024, 08:10:49 - Thibaultmol: (i assume stuff like building type, just like regular grb import tool?)
Fri, Feb 9, 2024, 22:20:51 - pietervdvn: Building type should be verified manually, but also conflicting landuse. If landuse overlaps with a building (e.g. the border of a residential area), the overlapping buildings will _not_ be imported with the auto-tool. So those should be corrected and added afterwards

And where do the GRB tags from the MP go when you shrinkwrap?

Mon, Mar 11, 2024, 00:16:15 - pietervdvn: Good to see that you already say hello here!

This is the channel where we discuss all things specific to the GRB import.

Please, have a look to the "advanced" flow how other people do it: https://matrix.org/_matrix/media/r0/download/matrix.org/xeWAIiNCPOTKYpkwovRvjaIv

MapComplete automates some of this, but (as you noticed) it has its own issues. Reading the JOSM workflow gives a different perspective
